editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Nayoon Ahn

respStmt.resp: Tokenization and linguistic annotation using MorphAdorner and NUPOS 2.0 were provided by
respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: Project co-ordination and review of textual changes and linguistic annotation by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

div.p: The white devil, or, the tragedy of Paulo Giordano Ursini, Duke of Brachiano, with the life and death of Vittoria Corombona the famous Venetian courtesan.
Acted by the Queen's majesty's servants.
London, printed by N. O. for Thomas archer, and are to be sold at his shop in Pope's head palace, near the royal exchange. 1612.

div.head: To the reader.
div.p:
In publishing this tragedy, I do but challenge to myself that liberty, which other men have ta'en before me; not that I affect praise by it, for, nos haec novimus esse nihil, only since it was acted, in so dull a time of winter, presented in so open and black a theater, that it wanted (That which is the only grace and setting out of a tragedy) a full and understanding auditory: and that since that time I have noted, most of the people that come to that playhouse, resemble those ignorant asses (Who visiting stationer's shops their use is not to inquire for good books, but new books) I present it to the general view with this confidence.
Nec rhoncos metues, maligniorum,
Nec scombris tunicas, dabis molestas.

If it be objected this is no true dramatic poem, I shall easily confess it, non potes in nugas dicere plura meas: ipse ego quam dixi, willingly, and not ignorantly, in this kind have I faulted: for should a man present to such an auditory, the most sententious tragedy that ever was written, observing all the critical laws, as height of style; and gravity of person; enrich it with the sententious chorus, and as it
were life'n death, in the passionate and weighty nuntius: yet after all this divine rapture, oh dura messorum ilia, the breath that comes from the uncapable multitude, is able to poison it, and ere it be acted, let the author resolve to fix to every scene, this of Horace,
— Haec hodie porcis comedenda relinques.

To those who report I was a long time in finishing this tragedy, I confess I do not write with a goose-quill, winged with two feathers, and if they will needs make it my fault, I must answer them with that of Eurypides to Alcestides, a tragic writer: Alcestides objecting that Eurypides had only in three days composed three verses, whereas himself had written three hundreth: thou tellst truth, (Quoth he) but here's the difference, thine shall only be read for three days, whereas mine shall continue three ages.

Detraction is the sworn friend to ignorance: for mine own part I have ever truly cherished my good opinion of other men's worthy labours, especially of that full and haightned style of master Chapman. The laboured and understanding works of master Johnson: the no less worthy composures of the both worthily excellent master Beaumont, and master Fletcher: and lastly (Without wrong last to be named) the right happy and copious industry of m. Shakespeare, m. Decker, and m. Heywood, wishing what I write may be read by their light: protesting, that, in the strength of mine own judgement, I know them so worthy, that though I rest silent in my own work, yet to most of theirs I dare (Without flattery) fix that of martial.

div.head: The tragedy of Paulo Giordano Ursini Duke of Brachiano, and Vittoria Corombona.

sp.stage: Enter count Lodovico, Antonelli and Gasparo.

sp.speaker: Lodovico.
sp.l: Banished?

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: It grieved me much to hear the sentence.

sp.speaker: Lodo.
sp.l: Ha, ha, o Democritus thy gods
That govern the whole world! Courtly reward, and punishment. Fortune's a right whore.
If she give ought, she deals it in small parcels,
That she may take away all at one swoop.
This 'tis to have great enemies, God quite them:
Your wolf no longer seems to be a wolf
Then when she's hungry.

sp.speaker: Gas.
sp.l: You term those enemies
Are men of princely rank.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: O I pray for them.
The violent thunder is adored by those
Are pashed in pieces by it.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: Come my lord,
You are justly doomed, look but a little back
Into your former life: you have in three years
Ruined the noblest earldom

sp.speaker: Gas.
sp.l: Your followers
Have swallowed you like mummia, and being sick
With such unnatural and horrid physic
Vomit you up ith' kennel

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: All the damnable degrees
of drinkings have you, you staggered through one citizen.
Is lord of two fair manors, called you master
Only for caviar.

sp.speaker: Gas.
sp.l: Those noblemen
Which were invited to your prodigal feasts,
Wherein the phoenix scarce could scape your throats,
Laugh at your misery, as foredeeming you:
An idle meteor which drawn forth the earth
Would be soon lost ith' air.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: Jest upon you,
And say you were begotten in an earthquake,
You have ruined such fair lordships.

sp.speaker: Lodo.
sp.l: Very good,
This well goes with two buckets, I must tend
The pouring out of eather.

sp.speaker: Gas.
sp.l: Worse than these,
You have acted, certain murders here in Rome,
Bloody and full of horror.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: 'Las they were flea-bitings?
Why took they not my head then?

sp.speaker: Gas.
sp.l: O my lord
The law doth sometimes mediate, thinks it good
Not ever to steep violent sins in blood,
This gentle penance may both end your crimes,
And in the example better these bad times.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: So, but I wonder then some great men scape
This banishment, there's Paulo Giordano Orfani,
The Duke of Brachiano, now lives in Rome,
And by close pandarism seeks to prostitute
The honour of Vittoria Corombona,
Vittoria, she that might have got my pardon
For one kiss to the Duke.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: Have a full man within you,
We see that trees bear no such pleasant fruit
There where they grew first, as where the are new set.
Perfumes the more they are chafed the more they render
Their pleasing scents, and so affliction
Expresseth virtue, fully, whether true,
Or else adulterate.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Leave your painted comforts,
I'll make Italian cut-works in their guts
If ever I return.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.l: O sir.

sp.speaker: Lodo.
sp.l: I am patient,
I have seen some ready to be executed
Give pleasant looks, and money, and grown familiar
With the knave hangman, so do I, I thank them,
and would account them nobly merciful
Would they dispatch me quickly,

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: Fare you well,
We shall find time I doubt not to repeal
Your banishment.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I am ever bound to you:
This is the world's alms; pray make use of it,
Great men sell sheep, thus to be cut in pieces,
When first they have shorn them bare and sold their fleeces.
sp.stage: Enter Brachiano, Camillo, Flamineo, Uittoria Corombona.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Your best of rest.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: Unto my lord the Duke,
The best of well come, more lights, attend the Duke.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Flamineo.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: My lord.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Quite lost Flamineo.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Pursue your noble wishes, I am prompt
As lightning to your service, o my lord!
The fair Vittoria, my happy sister
Shall give you present audience, gentlemen
Let the caroche go on, and 'tis his pleasure
You put out all your torches and depart.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Are we so happy.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Can't be otherwise?
Observed you not tonight my honoured lord
Which way soe'er you went she threw her eyes,
I have dealt already with her chambermaid
Zanche the more, and she is wondrous proud
To be the agent for so high a spirit.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: We are happy above thought, because 'bove merit.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: 'bove merit! we may now talk freely:'bove merit; what is't you doubt, her coyness, that's but the superficies of lust most women have; yet why should ladies blush to hear that named, which they do not fear to handle? O they are politic, they know our desire is increased by the difficulty of enjoying; where a satiety is a blunt, weary and drowsy passion, if the buttery hatch at court stood continually open their would be nothing so passionate crowding, nor hot suit after the beverage,

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: O but her jealous husband.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p:
Hang him, a guilder that hath his brains perished with
quicksilver is not more could in the liver. The great barriers moulted not more feathers than he hath shed hairs, by the confession of his doctor. An Irish gamester that will play himself naked, and then wage all downward, at hazard, is not more venturous. So unable to please a woman that like a Dutch doublet all his back is shrunk into his breeches.
Shroud you within this closet, good my lord,
Some trick now must be thought on to divide
My brother in law from his fair bedfellow,

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: O should she fail to come,

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: I must not have your lordship thus unwisely amorous,
sp.p: I myself have loved a lady and pursued her with a great deal of underage protestation, whom some 3. or 4. gallants that have enjoyed would with all their hearts have been glad to have been rid of 'tis just like a summer birdcage in a garden, the birds that are without, despair to get in, and the birds that are within despair and are in a consumption for fear they shall never get out: away away my lord,
sp.l: See here he comes, this fellow by his apparel
Some men would judge a politician,
But call his wit in question you shall find it
Merely an ass in's foot cloth,
How now brother what travailing to bed to your kind wife?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: I assure you brother no, my voyage lies
More northerly, in a far colder clime,
I do not well remember I protest when I last lay with her.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Strange you should lose your count.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: We never lay together but ear morning
Their grew a flaw between us.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: T'had been your part
To have made up that flaw.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: True, but she loathes I should be seen in't.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Why sir, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: The Duke your master visits me I thank him,
And I perceive how like an earnest bowler
He very passionately leans that way,
He should have his bowl run

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: I hope you do not think

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: That noble men boul booty, faith his cheek
Hath a most excellent bias, it would fain jump with my mistress.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Will you be an ass.
Despite you Aristotle or a cuckold
Contrary to your Ephemerides
Which shows you under what a smiling planet
You were first swaddled,

sp.speaker: Cam:
sp.l: Pew wew, sir tell not me
Of planets nor of ephemeridas
A man may be made cuckold in the day time
When the stars eyes are out.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Sir God boy you,
I do commit you to your pitiful pillow
Stuffed with horn-shavings.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Brother.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: God refuse me
Might I advise you now your only course
Wear to lock up your wife.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: 'Twere very good.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Bar her the sight of revels.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Excellent.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Let her not go to church, but like a hound
In Leon at your heels.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: 'Twere for her honour

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: And so you should be certain in one fortnight,
Despite her chastity or innocence
To be cuckolded, which yet is in suspense:
This is my counsel and I ask no see for't.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Come you know not where my night cap wrings me.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: Wear it ath' old fashion, let your large ears come through, it will be more easy, nay I will be bitter, bar your wife of her entertainment: women are more willingly and more gloriously chaste, when they are least restrained of their liberty. It seems you would be a fine capricious mathematically jealous coxcomb, take the height of your own horns with a Jacob's staff afore they are up. These politic enclosures for paltry mutton, makes more rebellion in the flesh then all the provocative electuaries doctors have uttered sense last jubilee.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: This doth not physic me,

sp.speaker: Fla:
sp.p:
It seems you are jealous, I'll show you the error of it by a familiar example, I have seen a pair of spectacles fashioned with such perspective art, that lay down but one twelve pence ath' board 'twill appear as if there were twenty, now should you
wear a pair of these spectacles, and see your wife tying her shoe, you would imagine twenty hands were taking up of your wife's clothes, and this would put you into a horrible causeless fury,

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: The fault there sir is not in the eyesight

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: True, but they that have the yellow jaundice, think all objects they look on to be yellow. Jealousy is worser, her fit's present to a man, like so many bubbles in a basin of water, twenty several crabbed faces, many times makes his own shadow his cuckold-maker. * see she comes, what reasonenter Corombona. have you to be jealous of this creature? what an ignorant ass or flattering knave might he be counted, that should write sonnets to her eyes, or call her brow the snow of Ida, or ivory of Corinth, or compare her hair to the black birds bill, when 'tis liker the black birds feather. This is all: be wise, I will make you friends and you shall go to bed together, marry look you, it shall not be your seeking, do you stand upon that by any means, walk you a loof, I would not have you seen in't, sister my lord attends you in the banquetting house, your husband is wondrous discontented.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.p: I did nothing to displease him, I carved to him at suppertime

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: You need not have carved him in faith, they say he is a capon already, I must now seemingly fall out with you. Shall a gentleman so well descended as Camillo. — a lousy slave that within this twenty years road with the black guard in the Duke's carriage amongst spits and dripping-pans.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Now he begins to tickle her.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: An excellent scholar, one that hath a head filled with calf's brains without any sage in them, — come crouching in the hams to you for a night's lodging — that hath an itch in's hams, which like the fire at the glass house hath not gone out this seven years — is he not a courtly gentleman, — when he wears white satin one would take him by his black mussel to be no other creature than a maggot, you are a goodly foil, I confess, well set out — but covered with a false stone you counterfeit diamond.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: He will make her know what is in me.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: Come, my lord attends you, thou shalt go to bed to my lord.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Now he comes to't.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: With a relish as curious as a vintner going to taste new wine, I am opening your case hard.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: A virtuous brother a my credit.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: He will give thee a ring with a philosopher's stone in it.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Indeed I am studying alchemy.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: Thou shalt lie in a bed stuffed with turtles feathers, swoon in perfumed linen like the fellow was smothered in roses, so perfect shall be thy happiness, that as men at sea think land and trees and ships go that way they go, so both heaven and earth shall seem to go your voyage. Shalt meet him, 'tis fixed, with nails of diamonds to inevitable necessity.

sp.speaker: Vitto.
sp.l: How shall's rid him hence?

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: I will put breeze in's tail, set him gadding presently, I have almost wrought her to it, I find her coming, but might I advise you now for this night I would not lie with her, I would cross her humour to make her more humble.

sp.speaker: Camil.
sp.l: Shall I, shall I?

sp.speaker: Fla:
sp.l: It will show in you a supremacy of judgement.

sp.speaker: Camil.
sp.p: True, and a mind differing from the tumultuary opinion, for quae negata great.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: Right you are the adamant shall draw her to you, though you keep distance of:

sp.speaker: Camil.
sp.l: A philosophical reason.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: Walk by her a'the noble man's fashion, and tell her you will lie with her at the end of the progress

sp.speaker: Camil.
sp.p: Vittoria, I cannot be induced, or as a man would say incited.

sp.speaker: Vitto.
sp.l: To do what sir?

sp.speaker: Camil.
sp.p: To lie with you tonight ; your silkworm useth to fast every third day, and the next following spins the better. Tomorrow at night I am for you.

sp.speaker: Vitto.
sp.l: You'll spin a fair thread, trust to't.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: But do you hear I shall have you steal to her chamber about midnight.

sp.speaker: Camil.
sp.p:
Do you think so, why look you brother, because
you shall not think I'll gull you, take the key, lock me into the chamber, and say you shall be sure of me.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Introth I will, I'll be your jailer once,
But have you ne'er a false door.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: A pox on't, as I am a christian tell me tomorrow how scurvily she takes my unkind parting

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: I will.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Didst thou not make the jest of the silkworm? good night in faith I will use this trick often,

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Do, do, do.
sp.p: So now you are safe. Ha ha ha, thou entanglest thyself in thine own work like a silkworm

Come sister, darkness hides your blush, women are like cursed dogs, civility keeps them tied all day time, but they are let loose at midnight, than they do most good or most mischief, my lord, my lord

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Give credit: I could wish time would stand still
And never end this interview this hour,
sp.stage: Zanche brings out a carpet spreads it and lays on it two fair cushions enter Cornelia
sp.l: But all delight doth itself soonest devour.
Let me into your bosom happy lady,
Pour out in stead of eloquence my vows,
Lose me not madam, for if you forego me I am lost eternally.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: Sir in the way of pity I wish you heart-whole.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: You are a sweet physician.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: Sure sir a loathed cruelty in ladies
Is as to doctors many funerals: it takes away their credit.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Excellent creature.
We call the cruel fair, what name for you
That are so merciful?

sp.speaker: Zan.
sp.l: See now they close.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Most happy union.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: My fears are fallen upon me, o my heart!
My son the pandar: now I find our house
Sinking to ruin. Earthquakes leave behind,
Where they have tyrannised, iron, or lead, or stone,
But woe to ruin violent lust leaves none

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: What value is this jewel

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: 'Tis the ornament of a weak fortune.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: In sooth I'll have it; nay I will but change
my jewel for your jewel.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.l: Excellent,
His jewel for her jewel, well put in Duke.

sp.speaker: Brac.
sp.l: Nay let me see you wear it.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: Hear sir.

sp.speaker: Brac.
sp.l: Nay lower, you shall wear my jewel lower.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.l: That's better she must wear his jewel lower.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: To pass away the time I'll tell your grace,
A dream I had last night.

sp.speaker: Brac.
sp.l: Most wishedly.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: A foolish idle dream,
Methought I walked about the mid of night,
Into a churchyard, where a goodly yew tree
Spread her large root in ground, under that yew,
As I sat sadly leaning on a grave,
Chequered with cross-sticks, their came stealing in
Your Duchess and my husband, one of them
A pickax bore, th'other a rusty spade,
And in rough terms they 'gan to challenge me,
About this eu.

sp.speaker: Brac.
sp.l: That tree.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: This harmless yew:
They told me my intent was to root up
That well-grown yew, and plant i'th steed of it
A withered blackthorn, and for that they vowed
To bury me alive: my husband straight
With pickax 'gan to dig, and your fell Duchess
With shovel, like a fury, voided out
The earth and scattered bones, lord how methought
I trembled, and yet for all this terror
I could not pray.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.l: No the devil was in your dream.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: When to my rescue there arose methought
A whirlwind, which let fall a massy arm
From that strong plant,
And both were struck dead by that sacred yew
In that base shallow grave that was their due.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.l: Excellent devil.
She hath taught him in a dream
To make away his Duchess and her husband.

sp.speaker: Brac.
sp.l: Sweetly shall I interpret this your dream,
You are lodged within his arms who shall protect you,
from all the fevers of a jealous husband,
From the poor envy of our phlegmatic Duchess,
I'll seat you above law and above scandal,
Give to your thoughts the invention of delight
And the fruition, nor shall government
Divide me from you longer than a care
To keep you great: you shall to me at once,
Be dukedom, health, wife, children, friends and all.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Woe to light hearts they still forerun our fall.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.l: What fury raised thee up? away, away

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: What make you hear my lord this dead of night?
Never dropped mildew on a flower here, tell now.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.l: I pray will you go to bed then,
Lest you be blasted.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: O that this fair garden,
Had all poisoned herbs of Thessaly,
At first been planted, made a nursery
For witchcraft; rather a burial plot,
For both your honours.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: Dearest mother hear me.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: O thou dost make my brow bend to the earth,
Sooner than nature, see the curse of children
In life they keep us frequently in tears,
And in the cold grave leaves us in pale fears.

sp.speaker: Brac.
sp.l: Come, come, I will not hear you.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: Dear my lord.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Where is thy Duchess now adulterous Duke?
Thou little dreamtst this night she is come to Rome.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.l: How? come to Rome,

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: The Duchess,

sp.speaker: Brac.
sp.l: She had been better,

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: The lives of princes should like dials move,
Whose regular example is so strong,
They make the times by them go right or wrong.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.l: So, have you done?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Unfortunate Camillo.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: I do protest if any chaste denial,
If any thing but blood could have allayed,
His long suit to me.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: I will join with thee,
To the most woeful end ere mother kneeled,
if thou dishonour thus thy husband's bed,
Be thy life short as are the funeral tears
In great men's.

sp.speaker: Brac.
sp.l: Fie, fie, the woman's mad.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Be thy act judas-like betray in kissing,
Mayest thou be envied during his short breath,
And pitied like a wretch after this death.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: O me accursed.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.l: Are you out of your wits, my lord
I'll fetch her back again?

sp.speaker: Brac.
sp.l: No I'll to bed.
Send doctor Julio to me presently,
Uncharitable woman thy rash tongue
Hath raised a fearful and prodigious storm,
Be thou the cause of all ensuing harm.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.l: Now, you that stand so much upon your honour,
Is this a fitting time a night think you,
To send a Duke home without ere a man:
I would fain know where lies the mass of wealth
Which you have hoarded for my maintenance,
That I may bear my beard out of the level
Of my lords stirrup.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: What? because we are poor,
Shall we be vicious?

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.l: Pray what means have you
To keep me from the galleys, or the gallows?
My father proved himself a gentleman,
Sold all's land, and like a fortunate fellow,
Died ere the money was spent. You brought me up,
At Padua I confess, where I protest
For want of means, the university judge me,
I have been fain to heel my tutor's stockings
At least seven years: conspiring with a beard
Made me a graduate, then to this Duke's service,
I visited the court, whence I returned:
More courteous, more lecherous by far,
But not a suit the richer, and shall I,
Having a path so open and so free
To my preferment, still retain your milk
In my pale forehead, no this face of mine
I'll arm and fortify with lusty wine,
'gainst shame and blushing.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: O that I never had born thee,

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.l: So would I.
I would the commonest courtesan in Rome,
Had been my mother rather than thyself.
Nature is very pitiful to whores
To give them but few children, yet those children
Plurality of fathers, they are sure
They shall not want. Go, go,
Complain unto my great lord Cardinal,
Yet may be he will justify the act.
Lycurgus wondered much men would provide
Good stallions for their mares, and yet would suffer
Their fair wives to be barren,

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Misery of miseries.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.l: The Duchess come to court, I like not that,
We are engaged to mischief and must on.
As rivers to find out the ocean
Flow with crook bendings beneath forced banks,
Or as we see to aspire some mountains top,
The way ascends not straight, but imitates
The subtle foldings of a winter's snake,
So who knows policy and her true aspect,
Shall find her ways winding and indirect.
sp.stage: Enter Francisco de Medicis, Cardinal Mountcelso, Marcello, Isabella, young Giovanni, with little Jaques the Moor.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Have you not seen your husband since you arrived?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Not yet sir.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Surely he is wondrous kind,
If I had a such dove-house as Camillo's
I would set fire on't, were't but to destroy
The polecats that haunt to't, — my sweet cousin.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Lord uncle you did promise me a horse
And armour.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: That I did my pretty cousin,
Marcello see it fitted.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: My lord the Duke is here.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Sister away you must not yet be seen.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: I do beseech you entreat him mildly,
Let not your rough tongue
set us at louder variance, all my wrongs
Are freely pardoned, and I do not doubt
As men to try the precious unicorn's horn
Make of the powder a preservative circle
And in it put a spider, so these arms
Shall charm his poison, force it to obeying
And keep him chaste from an infected straying

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I wish it may. Be gone.
Void the chamber,
You are welcome, will you sit, I pray my lord
Be you my orator, my hearts too full,
I'll second you anon.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Ere I begin
Let me entreat your grace forgo all passion
Which may be raised by my free discourse:

sp.speaker: Brac.
sp.l: As silent as i'th church you may proceed.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: It is a wonder to your noble friends,
That you have as 'twere entered the world,
With a free sceptre in your able hand,
And have to th'use of nature well applied
High gifts of learning, should in your prime-age
Neglect your awful throne, for the soft down
Of an insatiate bed. o my lord,
The drunkard after all his lavish cups,
Is dry, and then is sober, so at length,
When you awake from this lascivious dream,
Repentance then will follow; like the sting
Placed in the adder's tail: wretched are princes
When fortune blasteth but a petty flower
Of their unwieldy crowns; or ravisheth
But one pearl from their sceptre: but alas!
When they to wilful shipwreck lose good fame
All princely titles perish with their name.

sp.speaker: Brac.
sp.l: You have said my lord,

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Enough to give you taste
How far I am from flattering your greatness?

sp.speaker: Brac.
sp.l: Now you that are his second, what say you?
Do not like young hawks fetch a course about
your game flies fair and for you,

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Do not fear it:
I'll answer you in your own hawking phrase,
Some eagles that should gaze upon the sun
Seldom soar high, but take their lustful ease,
Since they from dunghill birds their pery can cease,
You know Vittoria,

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: You shift your shirt there
When you retire from tennis.

sp.speaker: Brac.
sp.l: Happily.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Her husband is lord of a poor fortune
Yet she wears cloth of tissue,

sp.speaker: Brac.
sp.l: What of this?
Will you urge that my good lord Cardinal
As part of her confession at next shrift,
And know from whence it sails.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: She is your strumpet,

sp.speaker: Brac.
sp.l: Uncivil sir there's hemlock in thy breath
And that black slander, were she a whore of mine
All thy loud cannons, and thy borrowed Switzers
Thy galleys, nor thy sworn confederates,
Durst not supplant her.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Let's not talk on thunder,
Thou hast a wife, our sister, would I had given
Both her whitehands to death, bound and locked fast
In her last winding sheer, when I gave thee
But one.

sp.speaker: Brac.
sp.l: Thou hadst given a soul to God then.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: True,
Thy ghostly father with all's absolution,
Shall never do so by thee.

sp.speaker: Brac.
sp.l: Spit thy poison,

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I shall not need, lust carries her sharp whip
At her own girdle, look to't for our anger
Is making thunderbolts.

sp.speaker: Brac.
sp.l: Thunder? in faith,
They are but crackers.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: We'll end this with the cannon.

sp.speaker: Brac.
sp.l: Thou'lt get naught by it but iron in thy wounds,
And gunpowder in thy nostrils.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Better that
Then change perfumes for plasters,

sp.speaker: Brac.
sp.l: Pity on thee,
'Twere good you'd show your slaves or men condemned
Your new ploughed forehead defiance, and I'll meet thee,
Even in a thicket of thy ablest men.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: My lords, you shall not word it any further
Without a milder limit.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Willingly.

sp.speaker: Brac.
sp.l: Have you proclaimed a triumph that you bait a
Lion thus.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: My lord.

sp.speaker: Brac.
sp.l: I am tame, I am tame sir.

sp.speaker: Flan.
sp.l: We send, unto the Duke for conference
Bout leauyes 'gainst the pirates, my lord Duke
Is not at home, we come ourself in person,
Still my lord Duke is busied, but we fear
When Tiber to each proling passenger
Discovers flocks of wild-ducks, than my lord
About moulting time, I mean we shall be certain
To find you sure enough and speak with you.

sp.speaker: Brac.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Flan.
sp.l: A mere tale of a tub, my words are idle,
But to express the sonnet by natural reason,
When stags grow melancholic you'll find the season

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: No more my lord, hear comes a champion,
Shall end the difference between you both,
Your son the prince Giovanni, see my lords
What hopes you store in him, this is a casket
For both your crowns, and should be held like dear:
Now is he apt for knowledge, therefore know
It is a more direct and even way
To train to virtue those of princely blood,
By examples then by precepts: if by examples
Whom should he rather strive to imitate
Then his own father: be his pattern then,
Leave him a stock of virtue that may last,
Should fortune rend his sails, and split his mast.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Your hand boy growing to soldier.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Give me a pike.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: What practising your pike so young, fair cous.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Suppose me one of Homer's frogs, my lord,
Tossing my bulrush thus, pray sir tell me
Might not a child of good discretion
Be leader to an army:

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Yes cousin a young prince
Of good discretion might.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Say you so,
Indeed I have heard 'tis fit a general
Should not endanger his own person oft,
So that he make a noise, when he's a horseback
Like a Dansk drummer, o 'tis excellent.
He need not fight, methinks his horse as well
Might lead an army for him; if I live
I'll charge the French foe, in the very front
Of all my troops, the foremost man.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: What, what,

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: And will not bid my soldiers up and follow
But bid them follow me.

sp.speaker: Brac.
sp.l: Forward lapwing.
He flies with the shell on's head.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Pretty cousin,

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: The first year uncle that I go to war,
All prisoners that I take I will set free
Without their ransom.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Ha, without their ransom,
How then will you reward your soldiers
That took those prisoners for you.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Thus my lord,
I'll marry them to all the wealthy widows
That falls that year.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Why then the next year following
You'll have no men to go with you to war.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Why then I'll press the women to the war,
And then the men will follow.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Witty prince.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: See a good habit makes a child a man,
Whereas a bad one makes a man a beast:
Come you and I are friends.

sp.speaker: Brac.
sp.l: Most wishedly,
Like bones which broke in sunder and well set
Knit the more strongly.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Call Camillo hither
You have received the rumor, how count Lodowick
Is turned a pirate.

sp.speaker: Brac.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: We are now preparing,
Some ships to fetch him in: behold your Duchess,
We now will leave you and expect from you
Nothing but kind entreaty.

sp.speaker: Brac.
sp.l: You have charmed me.
You are in health we see.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: And above health
To see my lord well,

sp.speaker: Brac.
sp.l: So I wonder much,
What amorous whirlwind hurried you to Rome

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Devotion my lord.

sp.speaker: Brac.
sp.l: Devotion?
Is your soul charged with any grievous sin

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: 'Tis burdened with too many, and I think
The oftener that we cast our reckonings up,
Our sleeps will be the sounder.

sp.speaker: Brac.
sp.l: Take your chamber?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Nay my dear lord I will not have you angry,
Doth not my absence from you two months,
merit one kiss?

sp.speaker: Brac.
sp.l: I do not use to kiss,
If that will dispossess your jealousy,
I'll swear it to you.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: O my loved lord,
I do not come to chide; my jealousy,
I am to learn what that Italian means,
You are as welcome to these longing arms,
As I to you a virgin.

sp.speaker: Brac.
sp.l: O your breath,
Out upon sweet meats, and continued physic.
The plague is in them.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: You have oft for these two lips
Neglected cassia or the natural sweets
Of the spring-violet, they are not yet much withered,
My lord I should be merry, these your frowns
Show in a helmet, lovely but on me,
In such a peaceful interview methinks
They are to too roughly knit.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: O dissemblance.
Do you bandy factions 'gainst me? have you learned,
The trick of impudent baseness to complain
Unto your kindred?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Never my dear lord.

sp.speaker: Brac.
sp.l: Must I be haunted out, or waste your trick
To meet some amorous gallant here in Rome
That must supply our discontinuance?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: I pray sir burst my heart, and in my death
Turn to your ancient pity, though not love.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Because your brother is the corpulent Duke,
That is the great Duke, 'sdeath I shall not shortly
Racket away five hundreth crowns at tennis,
But it shall rest upon record: I scorn him
Like a shaved pollack, all his reverent wit
Lies in his wardrobe, he's a discreet fellow
When he's made up in his robes of state,
Your brother the great Duke, because has galleys,
And now and then ransacks a Turkish flyboat,
(Now all the hellish furies take his soul,)
First made this match, accursed be the priest
That sang the wedding mass, and even my issue.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: O to too far you have cursed.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Your hand I'll kiss,
This is the latest ceremony of my love,
henceforth I'll never lie with thee, by this,
This wedding-ring: I'll ne'remore lie with thee.
And this divorce shall be as truly kept,
As if the judge had doomed it: fare you well,
Our sleeps are severed.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Forbid it the sweet union
Of all things blessed; why the saints in heaven
Will knit their brows at that.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Let not thy love,
Make thee an unbeliever, this my vow,
Shall never on my soul be satisfied
With my repentance: let thy brother rage
Beyond a horrid tempest or sea-fight,
My vow is fixed.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: O my winding sheet,
Now shall I need thee shortly, dear my lord,
Let me hear once more, what I would not hear,
Never.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Never?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: O my unkind lord may your sins find mercy,
As I upon a woeful widowed bed,
Shall pray for you, if not to turn your eyes,
Upon your wretched wife, and hopeful son,
Yet that in time you'll fix them upon heaven.

sp.speaker: Brac.
sp.l: No more, go, go, complain to the great Duke.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: No my dear lord, you shall have present witness,
How I'll work peace between you, I will make
Myself the author of your cursed vow
I have some cause to do it, you have none,
Conceal it I beseech you, for the weal
Of both your dukedoms, that you wrought the means
Of such a separation, let the fault
Remain with my supposed jealousy,
And think with what a piteous and rent hear,
I shall perform this sad ensuing part.
sp.stage: Enter Francisco, Flamineo, Montcello, Marcello, Camillo.

sp.speaker: Brac.
sp.l: Well, take your course my honourable brother.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Sister, this is not well my lord, why sister,
She merits not this welcome.

sp.speaker: Brac.
sp.l: Welcome say?
She hath given a sharp welcome.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Are you foolish?
Come dry your tears, is this a modest course.
To better what is naught, to rail and weep,
Grow to a reconcilement, or by heaven,
I'll ne'er more deal between you.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Sir you shall not,
No though Vittoria upon that condition
Would become honest.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Was your husband loud.
Since we departed.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: By my life sir no,
I swear by that I do not care to lose.
Are all these ruins of my former beauty,
Laid out for a whore's triumph?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Do you hear
Look upon other women, with what patience
They suffer these slight wrongs, with what justice
They study to requite them, take that course.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: O that I were a man, or that I had power
To execute my apprehended wishes,
I would whip some with scorpions.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: What? turned fury?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: To dig the strumpet's eyes out, let her lie
Some twenty months a dying, to cut off
Her nose and lips, pull out her rotten teeth,
Preserve her flesh like mummia, for trophies
Of my just anger: hell to my affliction
Is mere snow-water, by your favour sir,
Brother draw near, and my lord Cardinal,
Sir let me borrow of you but one kiss,
Henceforth I'll never lie with you, by this,
This wedding ring.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: How? ne'er more lie with him,

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: And this divorce shall be as truly kept,
As if in thronged court, a thousand ears
Had heard it, and a thousand lawyer's hands,
Sealed to the separation.

sp.speaker: Brac.
sp.l: Ne'er lie with me?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Let not my former dotage,
Make thee an unbeliever, this my vow
Shall never on my soul be satisfied
With my repentance, manet alta mente repositum.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Now by my birth you are a foolish, mad,
And jealous woman.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: You see 'tis not my seeking.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Was this your circle of pure unicorn's horn,
You said should charm your lord; now horns upon thee,
for jealousy deserves them, keep your vow,
And take your chamber.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: No sir I'll presently to Padua,
I will not stay a minute.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: O good madam.

sp.speaker: Brac.
sp.l: 'Twere best to let her have her humour.
Some half day's journey will bring down her stomach,
And then she'll turn in post.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: To see her come,
To my lord Cardinal for a dispensation
Of her rash vow will beget excellent laughter.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: "Unkindness do thy office, poor heart break,
" those are the killing griefs which dare not speak.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Camill's come my lord.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Where's the commission?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: 'Tis here.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Give me the signet.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: My lord do you mark their whispering, I will compound a medicine out of their two heads, stronger than garlic, deadlier than stibium, the Cantarides which are scarce seen to stick upon the flesh when they work to the heart, shall not do it with more silence or invisible cunning.

sp.speaker: Brac.
sp.l: About the murder.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: They are sending him to Naples, but I'll send him to Candy, here's another property to.

sp.speaker: Brac.
sp.l: O the doctor,

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: A poor quackesaluing knave, my lord, one that should have been lashed for's lechery, but that he confessed a judgement, had an execution laid upon him, and so put the whip to a nonplus.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: And was consigned, my lord, by an arranter knave than myself, and made pay all the colourable execution.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: He will shoot pills into a man's guts, shall make them have more ventages than a cornet or a lamprey, he will poison a kiss, and was once minded, for his masterpiece, because Ireland breeds no poison, to have prepared a deadly vapour in a Spaniards fart that should have poisoned all Dublin.

sp.speaker: Brac.
sp.l: O saint Anthony fire:

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Your secretary is merry my lord:

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p:
O thou cursed antipathy to nature, look his eyes bloodshed like a needle a chirurgeon stitcheth a wound with, let me embrace thee toad, and love thee o thou abominable loathsome gargarism, that will fetch up lungs, lights, heart, and liver
by scruples.

sp.speaker: Brac.
sp.l: No more, I must employ thee honest doctor,
You must to Padua and by the way, use some of your skill for us.

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.l: Sir I shall.

sp.speaker: Brac.
sp.l: But for Camillo?

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.l: He dies this night by such a politic strain,
Men shall suppose him by's own engine slain.
But for your Duchess death.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: I'll make her sure

sp.speaker: Brac.
sp.l: Small mischiefs are by greater made secure.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: Remember this you slave, when knaves come to preferment they rise as gallows are raised i'th low countries, one upon another shoulders.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Here is an emblem nephew pray peruse it.
'Twas thrown in at your window,

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: At my window,
Here is a stag my lord hath shed his horns,
And for the loss of them the poor beast weeps
The word inopem me copia fecit.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: That is.
Plenty of horns hath made him poor of horns.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: What should this mean.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: I'll tell you, 'tis given out
You are a cuckold.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Is it given out so.
I had rather such report as that my lord.
Should keep within doors.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Have you any children.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: None my lord.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: You are the happier
I'll tell you a tale.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Pray my lord.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: An old tale.
Upon a time Phoebus the god of light
Or him we call the sun would need be married.
The gods gave their consent, and Mercury
Was sent to voice it to the general world.
But what a piteous cry their straight arose
Amongst smiths, and feltmakers, brewers and cooks.
Reapers and butter-women, amongst fishmongers
And thousand other trades, which are annoyed
By his excessive heat; 'twas lamentable.
They came to Jupiter all in a sweat
And do forbid the banes; a great fat cook
Was made their speaker, who entreats of Jove
That Phoebus might be gelded, for if now
When there was but one, sun so many men,
wear like to perish by his violent heat.
What should they do if he were married
And should be more, and those children
Make fireworks like their father, so say I,
Only I will apply it to your wife,
Her issue should not providence prevent it
Would make both nature, time, and man repent it.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Look you cousin.
Go change the air for shame see if your absence,
Will blast your cornucopia, Marcello
Is chosen with you joint commissioner
For the relieving our Italian coast
From pirates.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I am much honoured in't.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: But sir
Ere I return the stags horns may be sprouted,
Greater than these are shed.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Do not fear it,
I'll be your ranger.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: You must watch i'th nights,
Then's the most danger.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Farewell good Marcello.
All the best fortunes of a soldier's wish,
Bring you a shipboard.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Were I not best now I am turned soldier,
Ere that I leave my wife, sell all she hath,
And then take leave of her.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: I expect good from you,
Your parting is so merry.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Merry my lord, a'th captain's humour right
I am resolved to be drunk this night.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: So, 'twas well fitted, now shall we discern,
How his wished absence will give violent way,
To Duke Brachiano's lust,

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Why that was it;
To what scorned purpose else should we make choice
Of him for a sea captain, and besides,
Count Lodowick which was rumoured for a pirate.
Is now in Padua.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Is't true?

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Most certain.
I have letters from him, which are suppliant
To work his quick repeal from banishment,
He means to address himself for pension,
Unto our sister Duchess.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: O 'twas well.
We shall not want his absence passed six days,
I fain would have the Duke Brachiano run
Into notorious scandal, for their's naught
In such cursed dotage, to repair his name,
Only the deep sense of some deathless shame:

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: It may be objected I am dishonourable,
To play thus with my kinsman, but I answer.
For my revenge I'd stake a brother's life,
That being wronged durst not avenge himself.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Come to observe this strumpet.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Curse of greatness,
Sure he'll not leave her.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: There's small pity in't
Like mistletoe on sere elms spent by weather,
Let him cleave to her and both rot together.
sp.stage: Enter Brachiano with one in the habit of a conjurer.

sp.speaker: Brac.
sp.l: Now sir I claim your promise, 'tis dead midnight,
The time prefixed to show me by your art,
How the intended murder of Camillo,
And our loathed Duchess grow to action.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: You have won me by your bounty to a deed,
I do not often practise, some there are,
Which by sophistic tricks, aspire that name
Which I would gladly lose, of necromancer:
As some that use to juggle upon cards,
Seeming to conjure, when indeed they cheat.
Others that raise up their confederate spirits,
About windmills, and endanger their own necks,
For making of a squib, and some their are
Will keep a curtal to show juggling tricks
And give out 'tis a spirit: besides these
Such a whole ream of almanac-makers, figure-flingers.
Fellows indeed that only live by stealth,
Since they do merely lie about stolen goods,
They'd make men think the devil were fast and loose,
With speaking fustian latin: pray sit down,
Put on this nightcap sir, 'tis charmed, and now
I'll show you by my strong-commanding art
The circumstance that breaks your duchess' heart.
sp.stage: Enter suspiciously, Julio and Christophero, they draw a curtain's where Brachian's picture is, they put on spectacles of glass, which cover their eyes and noses, and then burn perfumes afore the picture, and wash the lips of the picture, that done, quenching the fire, and putting off their spectacles they depart laughing.

Enter Isabella in her nightgown as to did-ward, with lights after her, count Lodovico, Giovanni, Guid-antonio and others weighting on her, she kneels down as to prayers, then draws the curtain of the picture, does three reverences to it, and kisses it thrice, she faints and will not suffer them to come ne'er it, dies, sorrow expressed in Giovanni and in count Lodovico, she's conveyed out solemnly.

sp.speaker: Brac.
sp.l: Excellent, then she's dead,

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: She's poisoned,
By the fumed picture, 'twas her custom nightly,
Before she went to bed, to go and visit
Your picture, and to feed her eyes and lips
On the dead shadow, doctor Julio
Observing this, infects it with an oil
And other poisoned stuff, which presently
Did suffocate her spirits.

sp.speaker: Brac.
sp.l: Methought I saw,
Count Lodowick there.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: He was, and by my art
I find he did most passionately dote
Upon your Duchess, now turn another way,
And view Camillo's far more politic face,
Strike louder music from this charmed ground,
To yield, as fits the act, a tragic sound.
sp.stage:
Enter Flamineo, Marcello, Camillo, with four more as captains, they drink healths and dance, a vaulting horse is brought into the room, Marcello and two more whispered out of the room, while Flamineo and Camillo strip themselves into their shirts, as to vault, compliment who shall begin, as Camillo it about to vault, Flamineo pitcheth him upon his neck, and with the help of the rest, writhes his neck about, seems to see if it be broke, and lays him folded double as 'twere under the hearse, makes 〈◊〉 to call for help.
Marcello comes in, laments, sends for the Cardinal and Duke, who comes forth with armed men, wonder at the act, commands the body to be carried home, apprehends Flamineo, Marcello, and the rest, and go as 'twere to apprehend Vittoria.

sp.speaker: Brac.
sp.l: 'Twas quaintly done, but yet each circumstance,
I taste not fully.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: O 'twas most apparent,
You saw them enter charged with their deep healths
To their boon voyage, and to second that,
Flamineo calls to have a vaulting horse
Maintain their sport. The virtuous Marcello,
Is innocently plotted forth the room,
Whilst your eye saw the rest, and can inform you
The engine of all.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: It seems Marcello, and Flamineo
Are both committed.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Yes, you saw them guarded,
And now they are come with purpose to apprehend
Your mistress, fair Vittoria; we are now
Beneath her roof: 'twere fit we instantly
Make out by some back postern:

sp.speaker: Brac.
sp.l: Noble friend,
You bind me ever to you, this shall stand
As the firm seal annexed to my hand.
It shall enforce a payment.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Sir I thank you.
Both flowers and weeds, spring when the sun is warm,
And great men do great good, or else great harm.
sp.stage: Enter Francisco, and Monticelso, their chancellor and register.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: You have dealt discreetly to obtain the presence,
Of all the grave leaguer ambassadors
To hear vittorias trial.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: 'Twas not ill,
For sir you know we have naught but circumstances
To charge her with, about her husband's death,
Their approbation therefore to the proofs
Of her black lust, shall make her infamous
To all our neighbouring kingdoms, I wonder (Pable
If Brachiano will be here.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: O fie 'twere impudence too pal -
sp.stage: Enter Flamineo and Marcello guarded, and a lawyer.

sp.speaker: Lavv.
sp.p:
What are you in by the week, so I will try now
whether thy wit be close prisoner, methinks none should sit upon thy sister but old whoremasters,

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: Or cuckolds, for your cuckold is your most terrible tickler of lechery: whoremasters would serve, for none are judges at tilting, but those that have been old tilters.

sp.speaker: Lavv.
sp.l: My lord Duke and she have been very private:

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: You are a dull ass, 'tis threatened they have been very public.

sp.speaker: Lavv.
sp.l: If it can be proved they have but kissed one another.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.l: What then?

sp.speaker: Lavv.
sp.l: My lord Cardinal will ferret them,

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.l: A Cardinal I hope will not catch coneys.

sp.speaker: Lavv.
sp.p: For to sow kisses (Mark what I say) to sow kisses, is to reap lechery, and I am sure a woman that will endure kissing is half won.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: True, her upper part by that rule, if you will win her nether part to, you know what follows.

sp.speaker: Lavv.
sp.l: Hark the ambassadors are lighted,

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.l: I do put on this feigned garb of mirth,
To gull suspicion.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: O my unfortunate sister!
I would my dagger's point had cleft her heart
When she first saw Brachiano: you 'tis said,
Were made his engine, and his stauking horse
To undo my sister.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.l: I made a kind of path
To her and mine own preferment.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Your ruin,

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.l: Hum! thou art a soldier,
Followest the great Duke, feedest his victories,
As witches do their serviceable spirits,
Even with thy prodigal blood, what hast got?
But like the wealth of captains, a poor handful,
Which in thy palm thou bearest, as men hold water
Seeking to gripe it fast, the frail reward
Steals through thy fingers.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Sir,

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.l: Thou hast scarce maintenance
To keep thee in fresh chamois.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Brother.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.l: Hear me,
And thus when we have even poured ourselves,
into great fights, for their ambition
Or idle spleen, how shall we find reward,
But as we seldom find the mistletoe
Sacred to physic: or the builder oak,
Without a mandrake by it, so in our quest of gain.
Alas the poorest of their forced dislikes
At a limb proffers, but at heart it strikes:
This is lamented doctrine.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Come, come.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.l: When age shall turn thee,
White as a blooming hawthorn.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I'll interrupt you.
For love of virtue bear an honest heart,
And stride over every politic respect,
Which where they most advance they most infect.
Were I your father, as I am your brother,
I should not be ambitious to leave you
A better patrimony.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: I'll think on't, the lord ambassadors.
sp.stage: Here there is a passage of the lieger ambassadors over the stage severally. Enter French ambassadors.

sp.speaker: Lavv.
sp.p: O my sprightly Frenchman, do you know him, he's an admirable tilter.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: I saw him at last tilting, he showed like a pewter candlestick fashioned like a man in armour, holding a tilting staff in his hand, little bigger than a candle of twelve i'th pound.

sp.speaker: Lavv.
sp.l: O but he's an excellent horseman.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: A lame one in his lofty tricks, he sleeps a horseback like a poulter,

sp.speaker: Lavv.
sp.l: Lo you my Spaniard.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: He carries his face in's ruff, as I have seen a servingman carry glasses in a cypress hatband, monstrous steady for fear of breaking, he looks like the claw of a blackbird, first salted and then broiled in a candle.
sp.stage: The araignement of Vittoria. Enter Francisco, Montcelso, the six lieger ambassadors, Brachiano, Uittoria, Isabella, lawyer, and a guard.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Forbear my lord, here is no place assigned you,
This business by his holiness is left
To our examination.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: May it thrive with you.
sp.stage: Lays a rich gown under him,

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: A chair there for his lordship.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Forbear your kindness, an unbidden guest
Should travail as Dutchwomen go to church:
Bear their stools with them.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: At your pleasure sir.
Stand to the table gentlewomen: now signior
Fall to your plea.
sp.stage: Dominae Judex convert oculos in hanc pestem mulierum corruptissimam.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: What's he?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: A lawyer, that pleads against you.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: Pray my lord, let him speak his usual tongue
I'll make no answer else.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Why you understand latin.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: I do sir, but amongst this auditory
Which come to hear my cause, the half or more
May be ignorant int'.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Go on sir:

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: By your favour,
I will not have my accusation clouded,
In a strange tongue: all this assembly
Shall hear what you can charge me with.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Signior.
You need not stand on't much; pray change your language,

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: O for God sake: gentlewoman, your credit
Shall be more famous by it.

sp.speaker: Lavv.
sp.l: Well then have at you.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: I am at the mark sir, I'll give aim to you,
And tell you how near you shoot.

sp.speaker: Lavv.
sp.l: Most literated judges, please your lordships,
So to connive your judgements to the view
Of this debauched and diversivolent woman
Who such a black concatenation
Of mischief hath effected, that to extirp
The memory of't, must be the consummation
Of her and her projections

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: What's all this

sp.speaker: Lavv.
sp.l: Hold your peace.
Exorbitant sins must have exulceration.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: Surely my lords this lawyer here hath swallowed
Some pothecaries bills, or proclamations.
And now the hard and undigestible words,
come up like stones we use give hawks for physic.
Why this is Welsh to latin.

sp.speaker: Lavv.
sp.l: My lords, the woman
Knows not her tropes nor figures, nor is perfect
In the academic derivation
Of grammatical elocution.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Sir your pains
Shall be well spared, and your deep eloquence
Be worthily applauded amongst those
Which understand you.

sp.speaker: Lavv.
sp.l: My good lord.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Sir,
Put up your papers in your fustian bag,
sp.stage: Francisco speaks this as in scorn.
sp.l: Cry mercy sir, 'tis buckram, and accept
My notion of your learned verbosity.

sp.speaker: Lavv.
sp.l: I most graduatically thank your lordship.
I shall have use for them elsewhere.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: I shall be plainer with you, and paint out
Your follies in more natural red and white.
Then that upon your cheek.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: O you mistake.
You raise a blood as noble in this cheek
As ever was your mothers.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: I must spare you till proof cry whore to that,
Observe this creature here my honoured lords,
A woman of a most prodigious spirit
In her effected.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: Honourable my lord,
It doth not suit a reverend Cardinal
To play the lawyer thus

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: O your trade instructs your language!
You see my lords what goodly fruit she seems,
Yet like those apples travellers report
To grow where Sodom and Gomora stood.
I will but touch her and you straight shall see
She'll fall to soot and ashes.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: Your envenomed pothecary should do't

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: I am resolved.
Were there a second paradise to lose
This devil would betray it.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: O poor charity!
Thou art seldom found in scarlet.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Who knows not how, when several night by night
Her gates were choked with coaches, and her rooms.
Outbraved the stars with several kind of lights,
When she did counterfeit a prince's court.
In music banquets and most riotous surfeits
This whore, forsooth, was holy.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: Ha? whore what's that?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Shall I expound whore to you? sure I shall;
I'll give their perfect character. They are first,
Sweet meats which rot the eater: in man's nostril
Poisoned perfumes. They are cozening alchemy,
Shipwracks in calmest weather? What are whores?
Cold Russian winters, that appear so barren,
As if that nature had forgotten the spring.
They are the true material fire of hell,
Worse than those tributes ith' low countries paid,
Exactions upon meat, drink, garments sleep.
I even on man's perdition, his sin.
They are those brittle evidences of law
Which forfeit all a wretched man's estate
For leaving out one syllable. What are whores?
They are those flattering bells have all one tune:
At weddings, and at funerals, your rich whores
Are only treasuries by extortion filled,
And empted by cursed riot. They are worse,
Worse than dead bodies, which are begged at gallows
And wrought upon by surgeons, to teach man
Wherein he is imperfect. What's a whore?
She's like the guilty conterfetted coin
Which who so ear first stamps it bring in trouble
All that receive it

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: This character scapes me.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: You gentlewoman;
Take from all beasts, and from all minerals
Their deadly poison.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: Well what then?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: I'll tell thee
I'll find in thee a pothecary's shop
To sample them all.

sp.speaker: Fr. Emb.
sp.l: She hath lived ill.

sp.speaker: Eng. and Emb.
sp.l: True, but the Cardinals too bitter.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: You know what whore is next the devil; adultery.
Enters the devil, murder.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Your unhappy husband
is dead.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: O he's a happy husband
Now he owes nature nothing.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: And by a vaulting engine.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: An active plot
He jumped into his grave.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: What a prodigy was't,
That from some two yards' height a slender man (More,
Should break his neck?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Ith' rushes.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: And what's.
Upon the instant lose all use of speech,
All vital motion, like a man had lain
Wound up three days. Now mark each circumstance.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: And look upon this creature was his wife.
She comes not like a widow: she comes armed
With scorn and impudence: is this a mourning habit.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: Had I foreknown his death as you suggest,
I would have bespoke my mourning.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: O you are cunning.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: You shame your wit and judgement
To call it so; what is my just defence
By him that is my judge called impudence?
Let me appeal then from this Christian court
To the uncivil tartar.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: See my lords.
She scandals our proceedings.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: Humbly thus.
Thus low, to the most worthy and respected
Leaguer ambassadors, my modesty
And womanhood I tender; but withal
So entangled in a cursed accusation
That my defence of force like Perseus.
Must personate masculine virtue to the point.
Find me but guilty, sever head from body:
We'll part good friends: I scorn to hold my life.
At yours or any man's entreaty, sir,

sp.speaker: Eng. Emb.
sp.l: She hath a brave spirit

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Well, well, such counterfeit jewels
Make true on's oft suspected.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: You are deceived.
For know that all your strict combined heads,
Which strike against this mine of diamonds,
Shall prove but glassen hammers, they shall break,
These are but feigned shadows of my evils.
Terrify babes, my lord, with painted devils,
I am passed such needless palsy, for your names,
Of whore and murderess they proceed from you,
As if a man should spit against the wind,
The filth returns in's face.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Pray you mistress satisfy me one question:
Who lodged beneath your roof that fatal night
Your husband broke his neck?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: That question
Enforceth me break silence, I was there.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Your business?

sp.speaker: Brac.
sp.l: Why I came to comfort her,
And take some course for settling her estate,
Because I heard her husband was in debt
To you my lord.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: He was.

sp.speaker: Brac.
sp.l: And 'twas strangely feared,
That you would cozen her.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Who made you overseer?

sp.speaker: Brac.
sp.l: Why my charity, my charity, which should flow
From every generous and noble spirit,
To orphans and to widows.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Your lust.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Cowardly dogs bark loudest. Sirrah priest,
I'll talk with you hereafter, — do you hear?
The sword you frame of such an excellent temper,
I'll sheath in your own bowels:
There are a number of thy coat resemble
Your common postboys.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Brac.
sp.l: Your mercenary postboys,
Your letters carry truth, but 'tis your guise
To fill your mouth's with gross and impudent lies.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: My lord your gown.

sp.speaker: Brac.
sp.l: Thou liest 'twas my stool.
Bestow't upon thy master that will challenge
The rest a'th householdstuff for Brachiano
Was ne'er so beggarly, to take a stool
Out of another's lodging: let him make
Valence for his bed on't, or a demi foot-cloth,
For his most reverent moil, Monticelso,
Nemo me impune lacescit.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Your champions gone.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: The wolf may prey the better.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: My lord there's great suspicion of the murder,
But no sound proof who did it: for my part
I do not think she hath a soul so black
To act a deed so bloody, if she have,
As in cold countries husbandmen plant vines,
And with warm blood manure them, even so
One summer she will bear unsavoury fruit,
And ere next spring wither both branch and root.
The act of blood let pass, only descend,
To matter of incontinence.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: I decern poison,
Under your guilded pills.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Now the duke's gone, I will produce a letter,
Wherein 'twas plotted, her and you should meet,
At an apothecary's summer-house.
Down by the river Tiber: view't my lords:
Where after wanton bathing and the heat
Of a lascivious banquet. — I pray read it,
I shame to speak the rest.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: Grant I was tempted,
Temptation to lust proves not the act,
Cast a est quam nemo rogavit,
You read his hot love to me, but you want
My frosty answer.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Frost i'th dog-days! strange!

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: Condemn you me for that the Duke did love me,
So may you blame so me fair and crystal river
For that some melancholic distracted man,
Hath drowned himself in't.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Truly drowned indeed.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: Sum up my faults I pray, and you shall find,
That beauty and gay clothes, a merry heart,
And a good stomach to feast, are all,
All the poor crimes that you can charge me with:
In faith my lord you might go pistol flies,
The sport would be more noble.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Very good.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: But take you your course, it seems you have beggared me
And now would fain undo me, I have houses, (First
Jewels, and a poor remnant of crusadoes,
Would those would make you charitable.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: If the devil
Did ever take good shape behold his picture.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: You have one virtue left,
You will not flatter me.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Who brought this letter?

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: I am not compelled to tell you.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: My lord Duke sent to you a thousand ducats,
The twelfth of August.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: 'Twas to keep your cousin
From prison, I paid use for't.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: I rather think
'Twas interest for his lust.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: Who says so but yourself? if you be my accuser
Pray cease to be my judge, come from the bench,
Give in your evidence 'gainst me, and let these
Be moderators: my lord Cardinal,
Were your intelligencing ears as loving
As to my thoughts, had you an honest tongue
I would not care though you proclaimed them all.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Go to, go to.
After your goodly and vainglorious banquet,
I'll give you a choke pear.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: A' your own grafting?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: You were born in Venice, honourably descended,
From the Vittelli, 'twas my cousin's fate,
Ill may I name the hour to marry you,
He bought you of your father.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: He spent there in six months
Twelve thousand ducats, and to my acquaintance
Received in dowry with you not one Julio:
'Twas a hard pennyworth, the ware being so light,
I yet but draw the curtain now to your picture,
You came from thence a most notorious strumpet,
And so you have continued.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: My lord.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Nay hear me,
You shall have time to prate my lord Brachiano,
Alas I make but repetition,
Of what is ordinary and Ryalto talk,
And ballasted, and would be played a'th stage,
But that vice many times finds such loud friends.
That preachers are charmed silent.
You gentlemen Flamineo and Marcello,
The court hath nothing now to charge you with,
only you must remain upon your sureties,
For your appearance.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I stand for Marcello.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: And my lord Duke for me.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: For you Vittoria, your public fault,
Joined to'th condition of the present time,
Takes from you all the fruits of noble pity.
Such a corrupted trial have you made
Both of your life and beauty, and been styled
No less in ominous fate then blazing stars
To princes .hear your sentence, you are confined,

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: Unto a house of convertites and your bawd.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Who I?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: The Moor.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: O I am a sound man again.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: A house of convertites, what's that?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: A house of penitent whores.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: Do the noblemen in Rome,
Erect it for their wives, that I am sent
To lodge there?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: You must have patience.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: I must first have vengeance.
I fain would know if you have your salvation
By patent, that you proceed thus.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Away with her?
Take her hence.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: A rape, a rape.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: Yes you have ravished justice,
Forced her to do your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Fie she's mad

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: Die with these pills in your most cursed maws,
Should bring you: health, or while you sit a'th bench,
Let your own spittle choke you.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: She's turned fury.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: That the last day of judgement may so find you,
And leave you the same devil you were before,
Instruct me some good horseleech to speak treason,
For since you cannot take my life for deeds,
Take it for words, o woman's poor revenge
Which dwells but in the tongue, I will not weep,
No I do scorn to call up one poor tear
To fawn one your injustice, bear me hence,
Unto this house of what's your mitigating title?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Of convertites.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: It shall not be a house of convertites
my mind shall make it honester to me
Then the Pope's palace, and more peaceable
Than thy soul, though thou art a Cardinal,
Know this, and let it some what raise your spite,
Through darkness diamonds spread their richest light.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Now you and I are friends sir, we'll shake hands,
In a friend's grave, together, a fit place,
Being the emblem of soft peace t'atone our hatred.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Sir, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: I will not chase more blood from that loved check,
You have lost too much already, fare-you-well.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: How strange these words sound? what's the interpretation?

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: Good, this is a preface to the discovery of the Duchess death: he carries it well: because now I cannot counterfeit a whining passion for the death of my lady, I will feign a mad humour for the disgrace of my sister, and that will keep off idle questions, treason's tongue hath a villainous palsy in't, I will talk to any man, hear no man, and for a time appear a politic madman.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: How now my noble cousin, what in black?

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Yes uncle, I was taught to imitate you
In virtue, and you must imitate me
In colours for your garments, my sweet mother
Is,

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: How? Where?

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Is there, no yonder, indeed sir I'll not tell you,
For I shall make you weep.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Is dead.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Do not blame me now,
I did not tell you so.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: She's dead my lord.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Dead?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Blessed lady;
Thou art now above thy woes,
Wilt please your lordships to withdraw a little.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: What do the dead do, uncle? do they eat,
Hear music, go a hunting, and be merry, as we that live?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: No cose; they sleep.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Lord, lord, that I were dead,
I have not slept these six nights. When do they wake?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: When God shall please.
Good God let her sleep ever.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: For I have known her wake an hundreth nights,
When all the pillow, where she laid her head,
Was brine-wet with her tears. I am to complain to you sir.
I'll tell you how they have used her now she's dead:
They wrapped her in a cruel fouled of lead,
And would not let me kiss her.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Thou didst love her.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: I have often heard her say she gave me suck,
And it should seem by that she dear loved me,
Since princes seldom do it.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: O, all of my poor sister that remains!
Take him away for god's sake.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: How now my lord?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Believe me I am nothing but her grave,
And I shall keep her blessed memory,
Longer than thousand epitaphs.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: We endure the strokes like anvils or hard steel,
Till pain itself make us no pain to feel.
sp.p: Who shall do me right now? Is this the end of service? I'd rather go weed garlic; travail through France, and be mine own ostler; wear sheepskin linings; or shoes that stink of blacking; be entered into the list of the forty thousand pedlars in Poland.
Would I had rotted in some surgeon's house at Venice, built upon the pox as well as on piles, ere I had served Brachiano.

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.l: You must have comfort.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: Your comfortable words are like honey. They relish well in your mouth that's whole; but in mine that's wounded they go down as if the sting of the bee were in them. O they have wrought their purpose cunningly, as if they would not seem to do it of malice. In this a politician imitates the devil, as the devil imitates a cannon. Wheresoever he comes to do mischief, he comes with his backside towards you.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: The proofs are evident.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p:
Proof! was corruption. O gold, what a god art thou! and o man, what a devil art thou to be tempted by that
cursed mineral! You diversivolent lawyer; mark him, knaves turn informers, as maggots turn to flies, you may catch gudgeons with either. A Cardinal; I would he would hear me, there's nothing so holy but money will corrupt and putrify it, like victual under the live. You are happy in England, my lord; here they sell justice with those weights they press men to death with. O horrible salary!

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.l: Fie, fie, Flamineo.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: Bells ne'er ring well, till they are at their full pitch, and I hope yond Cardinal shall never have the grace to pray well, till he come to the scaffold.

If they were racked now to know the confederacy! But your noblemen are privileged from the rack; and well may. For a little thing would pull some of them a pieces afore they came to their arraignment. Religion; o how it is commeddled with policy. The first bloodshed in the world happened about religion. Would I were a Jew.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: O, there are too many.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: You are deceived. There are not Jews enough;
Priests enough, nor gentlemen enough.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: I'll prove it. For if there were Jews enough, so many Christians would not turn usurers; if priests enough, one should not have six benefices; and if gentlemen enough, so many early mushrooms, whose best growth sprang from a dunghill, should not aspire to gentility. Farewell. Let others live by begging. Be thou one of them; practise the art of Wolnor in England to swallow all's given thee; and yet let one purgation make thee as hungry again as fellows that work in saw-pit. I'll go hear the screech-owl.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: This was Brachiano's pandar, and 'tis strange
That in such open and apparent guilt
Of his adulterous sister, he dare utter
So scandalous a passion. I must wind him.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: How dares this banished count return to Rome,
His pardon not yet purchased? I have heard
The deceased Duchess gave him pension,
And that he came along from Padua
I'th' train of the young prince. There's somewhat in 't.
Physicians, that cure poisons, still do work
With counterpoisons.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Mark this strange encounter.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: The god of melancholy turn thy gall to poison,
And let the stigmatic wrinkles in thy face,
Like to the boisterous waves in a rough tide
One still overtake another.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I do thank thee
And I do wish ingeniously for thy sake
The dog-days all year long.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: How croaks the raven?
Is our good Duchess dead?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Dead

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: O fate!
Misfortune comes like the crowner's business,
Huddle upon huddle.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Shalt thou and I join housekeeping?

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Yes, content.
Let's be unsociably sociable.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Sit some three days together, and discourse.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Only with making faces;
Lie in our clothes.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: With faggots for our pillows.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: And be lousy.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: In taffeta linings; that's gentile melancholy,
Sleep all day.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Yes: and like your melancholic hare
Feed after midnight.
We are observed: see how yond couple grieve.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: What a strange creature is a laughing fool,
As if man were created to no use
But only to show his teeth.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: I'll tell thee what,
It would do well in stead of looking glasses
To set ones face each morning by a saucer
Of a witch's congealed blood.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Precious gue.
We'll never part.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Never: till the beggary of courtiers,
The discontent of churchmen, want of soldiers,
And all the creatures that hang manacled,
Worse than strappadoed, on the lowest felly
Of fortune's wheel be taught in our two lives.
To scorn that world which life of means deprives.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: My lord, I bring good news. The Pope on's deathbed,
At th' earnest suit of the great Duke of Florence,
hath signed your pardon, and restored unto you —

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I thank you for your news. Look up again
Flamineo, see my pardon.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.l: Why do you laugh?
There was no such condition in our covenant.
