sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Why?

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.l: You shall not seem a happier man than I,
You know our vow sir, if you will be merry,
Do it i'th like posture, as if some great man
Sat while his enemy were executed:
Though it be very lechery unto thee,
Do't with a crabbed politician's face.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Your sister is a damnable whore.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Look you; I spoke that laughing.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.l: Dost ever think to speak again?

sp.speaker: Lod:
sp.l: Do you hear?
Wil't sell me forty ounces of her blood,
To water a mandrake?

sp.speaker: Fl.
sp.l: Poor lord; you did vow
To live a lousy creature.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Yes;

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Like one
That had for ever forfeited, the daylight,
By being in debt,

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Ha, ha?

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.l: I do not greatly wonder you do break:
Your lordship learned long since. But I'll tell you,

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: An't shall stick by you.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I long for it.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.l: This laughter scurvily becomes your face,
If you will not be melancholy, be angry.
See now I laugh too.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: You are to blame, I'll force you hence.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Unhand me:
That ere I should be forced to right myself,
Upon a pandar.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: My lord.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: He'd been as good met with his fist a thunderbolt.

sp.speaker: Gas.
sp.l: How this shows!

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Uds'death, how did my sword miss him?
These rogues that are most weary of their lives,
Still scape the greatest dangers,
A pox upon him: all his reputation;
Nay all the goodness of his family;
is not worth half this earthquake.
I learned it of no fencer to shake thus;
Come, I'll forget him, and go drink some wine.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Come, come my lord, untie your foulded thoughts,
And let them dangle loose as a bird's hair.
Your sister's poisoned.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Far be it from my thoughts
To seek revenge.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: What, are you turned all marble?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Shall I defy him, and impose a war
Most burdensome on my poor subjects' necks,
Which at my will I have not power to end?
You know; for all the murders, rapes, and thefts,
Committed in the horrid lust of war,
He that unjustly caused it first proceed,
Shall find it in his grave and in his seed.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: That's not the course I'd wish you: pray, observe me,
We see that undermining more prevails
Then doth the cannon, bear your wrongs concealed,
And, patient as the tortoise, let this camel
Stalk o'er your back unbruised: sleep with the lion,
And let this brood of secure foolish mice
Play with your nostrils, till the time be ripe
For th'bloody audit, and the fatal gripe:
Aim like a cunning fowler, close one eye,
That you the better may your game espy.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Free me my innocence; from treacherous acts:
I know there's thunder yonder: and I'll stand,
Like a safe valley, which low bends the knee
To some aspiring mountain: since I know
Treason, like spiders weaving nets for flies,
By her foul work is found, and in it dies.
To pass away these thoughts, my honoured lord,
It is reported you possess a book
Wherein you have quoted, by intelligence,
The names of all notorious offenders
lurking about the city,

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Sir I do
And some there are which call it my black book:
Well may the title hold: for though it teach not
The art of conjuring, yet in it lurk,
The names of many devils.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Pray let's see it.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: I'll fetch it to your lordship.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Monticelso,
I will not trust thee, but in all my plots
I'll rest as jealous as a town besieged.
Thou canst not reach what I intend to act.
Your flax soon kindles, soon is out again,
But gold slow heats, and long will hot remain.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: 'Tis here my lord.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: First your intelligencers pray let's see.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Their number rises strangely,
And some of them
You'd take for honest men.
Next are panders.
These are your pirates: and these following leaves,
For base rogues that undo young gentlemen,
By taking up commodities: for politic bankrupts:
For fellows that are bawds to their own wives,
Only to put off horses and slight jewels,
Clocks, defaced plate, and such commodities,
At birth of their first children.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Are there such?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: These are for impudent bawds,
That go in men's apparel: for usurers
That share with scriveners for their good reportage:
For lawyers that will antedate their writs:
And some divines you might find folded there;
But that I slip them o'er for conscience' sake.
Here is a general catalogue of knaves.
A man might study all the prisons o'er,
Yet never attain this knowledge.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Murderers.
Fould down the leaf I pray,
Good my lord let me borrow this strange doctrine.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Pray use't my lord.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I do assure your lordship,
You are a worthy member of the state,
And have done infinite good in your discovery
Of these offenders.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Somewhat sir.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: O God!
Better than tribute of wolves paid in England.
'Twill hang their skins o'th hedge.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: I must make bold
To leave your lordship.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Dear sir, I thank you,
If any ask for me at court, report
You have left me in the company of knaves.
I gather now by this, some cunning fellow
That's my lord's officer, one that lately skipped
From a clerk's desk up to a justice chair,
Hath made this knavish summons; and intends,
As th'irish rebels wont were to sell heads,
So to make prize of these. And thus it happens,
Your poor rogues pay for't, which have not the means
To present bribe in fist: the rest o'th' band
Are razed out of the knave's record; or else
My lord he winks at them with easy will,
His man grows rich, the knaves are the knaves still.
But to the use I'll make of it; it shall serve
To point me out a list of murderers,
Agents for any villainy. Did I want
Ten leash of courtesans, it would furnish me;
Nay laundress three armies. That so in little paper
Should lie th'unndo of so many men!
'Tis not so big as twenty declarations.
See the corrupted use some make of books:
Divinity, wrested by some factious blood,
Draws swords, swells battles, and o'erthrows all good.
To fashion my revenge more seriously,
Let me remember my dead sister's face:
Call for her picture: no; I'll close mine eyes,
And in a melancholic thought I'll frame
Her figure 'fore me. Now I — have't how strong
imagination works! how she can frame
Things which are not! methinks she stands afore me ▪
And by the quick idea of my mind,
Were my skill pregnant, I could draw her picture.
Thought, as a subtle juggler, makes us deem
Things, supernatural, which have cause
Common as sickness. 'tis my melancholy,
How cam'st thou by thy death? — how idle am I
To question mine own idleness? — did ever
Man dream awake till now? — remove this object
Out of my brain with't: what have I to do
With tombs, or deathbeds, funerals, or tears,
That have to meditate upon revenge?
So now 'tis ended, like an old wife's story.
Statesmen think often they see stranger sights
Than madmen, come, to this weighty business.
My tragedy must have some idle mirth in't,
Else it will never pass. I am in love,
In love with Corombona; and my suit
Thus halts to her in verse. —
I have done it rarely: o the fate of princes!
I am so used to frequent flattery,
That being alone I now flatter myself;
But it will serve, 'tis sealed; bear this
To th'house of convertites; and watch your leisure
To give it to the hands of Corombona,
Or to the matron, when some followers
Of Brachiano may be by. away
He that deals all by strength, his wit is shallow:
When a man's head goes through each limb will follow.
The engine for my business, bold count Lodowick:
'Tis gold must such an instrument procure,
With empty fist no man doth falcons lure.
Brachiano, I am now fit for thy encounter.
Like the wild Irish I'll ne'er think thee dead,
Till I can play at football with thy head.
Flectere sinequeo superes, acheronta movebo.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Should it be known the Duke hath such recourse.
To your imprisoned sister, I were like
T'incur much damage by it.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Not a scruple.
The Pope lies on his deathbed, and their heads
Are troubled now with other business
Than guarding of a lady.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Yonder's Flamineo in conference
With the matrona. Let me speak with you.
I would entreat you to deliver for me
This letter to the fair Vittoria.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: I shall sir.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: With all care and secrecy,
Hereafter you shall know me, and receive
Thanks for this courtesy.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: How now? what's that?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: A letter.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: To my sister: I'll see't delivered.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: What's that you read Flamineo?

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Look.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Ha? To the most unfortunate his best respected Vittoria.
Who was the messenger?

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: I know not.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: No! who sent it?

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Ud's foot you speak, as if a man
Should know what foul is coffined in a baked meat
Afore you cut it up.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: I'll open't, were't her heart. What's here subscribed
This juggling is gross and palpable. (Florence?
I have found out the conveyance; read it, read, it.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Your tears I'll turn to triumphs, be but mine.
Your prop is fallen; I pity that a vine
Which princes heretofore have longed to gather,
Wanting supporters, now should fade and wither.
Wine i'faith, my lord, with lees would serve his turn.
Your sad imprisonment I'll soon uncharm,
And with a princely uncontrolled arm
Lead you to Florence, where my love and care
Shall hang your wishes in my silver hair.
A halter on his strange equivocation.
Nor for my years return me the sad willow,
who prefer blossoms before fruit that's mellow.
Rotten on my knowledge with lying too long i'th bedstraw.
And all the lines of age this line convinces:
The gods never wax old, no more do princes.
Apox on't tear it, let's have no more atheists for God's sake.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Uds'death, I'll cut her into atomies
And let th'irregular northwind sweep her up
And blow her int'his nostrils. Where's this whore?

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: That? what do you call her?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: O, I could be mad,
Prevent the cursed disease she'll bring me to;
And tear my hair off. Where's this changeable stuff?

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: O'er head and ears in water, I assure you,
She is not for your wearing.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: In you pandar?

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: What me, my lord, am I your dog?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: A bloodhound: do you brave? do you stand me?

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Stand you? let those that have diseases run;
I need no plasters.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Would you be kicked?

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Would you have your neck broke?
I tell you Duke, I am not in Russia;
My shins must be kept whole.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Do you know me?

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: O my lord! methodically.
As in this world there are degrees of evils:
So in this world there are degrees of devils.
You're a great Duke; I your poor secretary.
I do look now for a Spanish fig, or an Italian salad daily.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Pandar, ply your convoy, and leave your prating.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: All your kindness to me is like that miserable courtesy of Polyphemus to Ulysses, you reserve me to be devoured last, you would dig turues out of my grave to feed your larks: that would be music to you. Come, I'll lead you to her.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Do you face me?

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: O sir I would not go before a politic enemy with my back towards him, though there were behind me a whirlpool.
sp.stage: Enter Vittoria to Brachiano and Flamineo.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Can you read mistress? look upon that letter;
There are no characters nor hieroglyphics.
You need no comment, I am grown your receiver,
God's precious you shall be a brave great lady,
A stately and advanced whore.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: Say sir.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Come, come, let's see your cabinet, discover
Your treasury of love-letters. Death and furies,
I'll see them all.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: Sir, upon my soul,
I have not any. Whence was this directed?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Confusion on your politic ignorance.
You are reclaimed; are you? I'll give you the bells
And let you fly to the devil.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Beware hawk, my lord.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: Florence! This is some treacherous plot, my lord,
To me, he ne'er was lovely I protest,
So much as in my sleep.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Right: they are plots.
Your beauty! O, ten thousand curses on't.
How long have I beheld the devil in crystal?
Thou hast led me, like an heathen sacrifice,
With music, and with fatal! yokes of flowers
To my eternal ruin. Woman to man
Is either a god or a wolf.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: My lord.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Away.
We'll be as differing as two adamants;
The one shall shun the other. What? dost weep?
Procure but ten of thy dissembling trade,
You'd furnish all the Irish funerals
With howling, passed wild Irish.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Fie, my lord.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: That hand, that cursed hand, which I have wearied
With doting kisses! O my sweetest Duchess
How lovely art thou now! Thy loose thoughts
Scatter like quicksilver, I was bewitched;
For all the world speaks ill of thee.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: No matter.
I'll live so now I'll make that world recant
And change her speeches. You did name your Duchess.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Whose death God pardon.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: Whose death God revenge
On thee most godless Duke.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Now for tow whirl winds.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: What have I gained by thee but infamy?
Thou hast stained the spotless honour of my house,
And frighted thence noble society:
like those, which sick 'Oth' palsy, and retain
Ill-scenting foxes about them, are still shunned
By those of choicer nostrils. What do you call this house?
Is this your palace? did not the judge style it
A house of penitent whores? who sent me to it?
Who hath the honour to advance Vittoria
To this incontinent college? is 't not you?
Is 't not your high preferment? Go, go brag
How many ladies you have undone, like me.
Fare you well sir; let me hear no more of you.
I had a limb corrupted to an ulcer,
But I have cut it off: and now I'll go
Weeping to heaven on crutches. For your gifts,
I will return them all; and I do wish
That I could make you full executor
To all my sins, ò that I could toss myself
Into a grave as quickly: for all thou art worth
I'll not shed one tear more; — I'll burst first.
sp.stage: She throws herself upon a bed.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: I have drunk Lethe.
Vittoria? My dearest happiness? Vittoria?
What do you ail my love? why do you weep?

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: Yes, I now weep poniards, do you see.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Are not those matchless eyes mine?

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: I had rather.
They were not matches.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Is not this lip mine?

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: Yes: thus to bite it off, rather than give it thee.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Turn to my lord, good sister.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: Hence you pandar.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Pandar! Am I the author of your sin?

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: Yes: he's a base thief that a thief lets in.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: We're blown up, my lord,

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Wilt thou hear me?
Once to be jealous of thee is to express
That I will love thee everlastingly,
And never more be jealous.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: O thou fool,
Whose greatness hath by much o'ergrown thy wit!
What dar'st thou do, that I not dare to suffer,
Excepting to be still thy whore? for that;
in the sea's bottom sooner thou shalt make
A bonfire.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: O, no oaths for god's sake.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Will you hear me?

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: Never.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: What a damned impostume is a woman's will?
Can nothing break it? fie, fie, my lord.
Women are caught as you take tortoises,
She must be turned on her back. Sister, by this hand
I am on your side. Come, come, you have wronged her.
What a strange credulous man were you, my lord,
To think the Duke of Florence could love her?
Will any mercer take another's beware
When once 't is toused and sullied? And, yet sister,
How scurvily this frowardness becomes you?
Young leverets stand not long; and women's anger
Should, like their flight, procure a little sport;
A full cry for a quarter of an hour;
And then be put to th' dead quat.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Shall these eyes,
Which have so long time dwelled upon your face,
Be now put out?

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: No cruel landlady 'Ith' world,
Which lends forth groats to broom-men, and takes use for them,
Would do't.
Hand her, my lord, and kiss her: be not like
A ferret to let go your hold with blowing.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Let us renew right hands.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: Hence.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Never shall rage, or the forgetful wine,
Make me commit like fault.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Now you are ith' way out, follow 'thard.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Be thou at peace with me; let all the world
Threaten the cannon.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Mark his penitence.
Best natures do commit the grossest faults,
When they're given o'er to jealousy; as best wine
Dying makes strongest vinegar. I'll tell you;
The sea's more rough and raging than calm rivers,
But nor so sweet nor wholesome. A quiet woman
Is a still water under a great bridge.
A man may shoot her safely.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: O ye dissembling men!

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p:
We sucked that, sister, from women's breasts, in our
first infancy.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: To add misery to misery.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Sweetest.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: Am I not low enough?
Ay, ay, your good heart gathers like a snowball
Now your affection's cold.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Uds'foot, it shall melt,
To a heart again, or all the wine in Rome
Shall run o'th lees for't.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: Your dog or hawk should be rewarded better
Than I have been. I'll speak not one word more.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Stop her mouth,
With a sweet kiss, my lord.
So now the tide's turned the vessel's come about
He's a sweet armful. O we curled-haired men
Are still most kind to women. This is well.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: That you should chide thus!

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: O, sir, your little chimneys
Do ever cast most smoke. I sweat for you.
Couple together with as deep a silence,
As did the Grecians in their wooden horse.
My lord supply your promises with deeds.
You know that painted meat no hunger feeds.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Stay ingrateful Rome. (Usage.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Rome! it deserves to be called Barbary, for our villainous

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Soft; the same project which the Duke of Florence,
(Whether in love or gullery I know not)
Laid down for her escape, will I pursue.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: And no time fitter than this night, my lord;
The Pope being dead; and all the Cardinals entered
The conclave for th' electing a new Pope;
The city in a great confusion;
We may attire her in a page's suit,
Lay her post-horse, take shipping, and amain
For Padua.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: I'll instantly steal forth the prince Giovanni,
And make for Padua. You two with your old mother
And young Marcello that attends on Florence,
If you can work him to it, follow me.
I will advance you all: for you Vittoria,
think of a Duchess title.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Lo you sister.
sp.p: Stay, my lord; I'll tell you a tale. The crocodile, which lives in the river Nilus, hath a worm breeds i'th teeth of't, which puts it to extreme anguish: a little bird, no bigger than a wren, is barber-surgeon to this crocodile; flies into the jaws of't; picks out the worm; and brings present remedy. The fish, glad of ease but ingrateful to her that did it, that the bird may not talk largely of her abroad for non payment, closeth her chaps intending to swallow her, and so put her to perpetual silence. But nature loathing such in gratitude, hath armed this bird with a quill or prick on the head, top o'th which wounds the crocodile i'th mouth; forceth her open her bloody prison; and away flies the pretty tooth-picker from her cruel patient.

sp.speaker: Brac.
sp.l: Your application is, I have not rewarded
The service you have done me.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.l: No, my lord;
sp.p: You sister are the crocodile: you are blemished in your fame, my lord cures it. And though the comparison hold not in every particle; yet observe, remember, what good the bird with the prick i'th head hath done you; and scorn ingratitude.
sp.l: It may appear to some ridiculous
Thus to talk knave and madman; and sometimes
Come in with a dried sentence, stuffed with sage.
But this allows my varying of shapes,
Knaves do grow great by being great men's apes.
sp.stage: Enter Francisco, Lodovico, Gasper, and six ambassadors.
At another door the Duke of Florence.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: So, my lord, I commend your diligence
Guard well the conclave, and, as the order is,
Let none have conference with the Cardinals.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I shall, my lord: room for the ambassadors,

sp.speaker: Gas.
sp.l: They're wondrous brave today: why do they wear
These several habits?

sp.speaker: Lod,
sp.l: O sir, they're knights
Of several order.
That lord i'th black cloak with the silver cross
Is knight of Rhodes; the next knight of s. Michael ▪
That of the golden fleece; the Frenchman there
Knight of the holy-ghost; my lord of Savoy
knight of th'annunciation; the Englishman
Is knight of th'honoured garter, dedicated
Unto their saint, s. George. I could describe to you
Their several institutions, with the laws
Annexed to their order, but that time
Permits not such discovery.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Where's count Lodowick?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Here my lord.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: 'Tis o'th point of dinnertime,
Marshal the Cardinal's service,

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Sir I shall.
sp.stage: Enter servants with several dishes covered.
sp.l: Stand, let me search your dish, who's this for?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: For my lord Cardinal Monticelso,

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Who's this?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: For my lord Cardinal of Burbon.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Why doth he search the dishes, to observe
What meat is dressed?

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.l: No sir, but to prevent.
Lest any letters should be conveyed in
To bribe or to solicit the advancement
Of any Cardinal, when first they enter
'Tis lawful for the ambassadors of princes
To enter with them, and to make their suit
For any man their prince affecteth best;
But after, till a general election,
No man may speak with them.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: You that attend on the lord Cardinals
Open the window, and receive their viands.

sp.speaker: A Car.
sp.l: You must return the service; the l. Cardinals
Are busied about electing of the Pope,
They have given o'er scrutiny, and are fallen
To admiration.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Away, away.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I'll lay a thousand ducats you here news
Of a Pope presently, hark; sure he's elected,
Behold! my lord of Arragon appears,
On the church battlements.

sp.speaker: Arragon.
sp.p: Denuntio vobis gaudium magnum. Reverendissimus cardinalis Lorenzo de Monticelso electus est in sedem apostolicam, et elegit sibinomen paulum quartum.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Uivat sanctus pater Paulus quartus.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Vittoria my lord.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Well: what of her?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Is fled the city,

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: With Duke Brachiano.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Fled? Where's the prince

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Gone with his father. (Giovanni

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Let the matrona of the convertites
Be apprehended: fled o damnable!
How fortunate are my wishes. Why? 'twas this
I only laboured. I did send the letter
T'instruct him what to do. Thy fame, fond Duke,
I first have poisoned; directed thee the way
To marry a whore; what can be worse? This follows ▪
The hand must act to drown the passionate tongue,
I scorn to wear a sword and prate of wrong.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: My lord reports Vittoria Corombona
Is stol'n from forth the house of convertites
By Brachiano, and they're fled the city.
Now, though this be the first day of our state,
We cannot better please the divine power,
Than to sequester from the holy church
These cursed persons. Make it therefore known,
We do denounce excommunication
Against them both: all that are theirs in Rome
We likewise banish. Set on.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Come dear Lodovico.
You have ta'en the sacrament to prosecute
Th' intended murder.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: With all constancy.
But, sir, I wonder you'll engage yourself,
In person, being a great prince.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Divert me not.
Most of his court are of my faction,
And some are of my council. Noble friend,
Our danger shall be 'Like in this design,
Give leave, part of the glory may be mine.
Why did the Duke of Florence with such care
Labour your pardon? say.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Italian beggars will resolve you that
who, begging of an alms, bid those they beg of
Do good for their own sakes; or't may be
He spreads his bounty with a sowing hand,
Like Kings, who many times give out of measure;
Not for desert so much as for their pleasure.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: I know you're cunning. Come, what devil was that
That you were raising?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Devil, my lord?
I ask you.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: How doth the Duke employ you, that his bonnet
Fell with such compliment unto his knee,
When he departed from you?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Why, my lord,
He told me of a resty Barbary horse
Which he would fain have brought to the career,
The assault, and the ring galliard. Now, my lord,
I have a rare French rider.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Take you heed:
Lest the jade break your neck. Do you put me off
With your wild horse-tricks? Sirrah you do lie.
O, thou'rt a foul black cloud, and thou dost threat
A violent storm.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Storms are ith' air, my lord;
I am too low to storm.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Wretched creature!
I know that thou art fashioned for all ill,
Like dogs, that once get blood, they'll ever kill.
About some murder? was't not?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I'll not tell you;
And yet I care not greatly if I do;
Marry with this preparation. Holy father,
I come not to you as an intelligencer,
But as a penitent sinner. What I utter
Is in confession merely; which you know
Must never be revealed.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: You have o'erta'en me.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Sir I did love Brachiano's Duchess dear;
Or rather I pursued her with hot lust,
Though she ne'er knew on't. She was poisoned;
Upon my soul she was: for which I have sworn
T'avenge her murder.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: To the Duke of Florence?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: To him I have.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Miserable creature!
If thou persist in this, 'tis damnable.
Dost thou imagine thou canst slide on blood
and not be tainted with a shameful fall?
Or like the black, and melancholic yew-tree,
Dost think to root thyself in dead men's graves,
And yet to prosper? Instruction to thee
Comes like sweet showers to over-hardened ground:
They wet, but pierce not deep. And so I leave thee
Withal the furies hanging bout thy neck,
Till by thy penitence thou remove this evil,
In conjuring from thy breast that cruel devil.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I'll give it o'er. He says 'tis damnable:
Besides I did expect his suffrage,
By reason of Camillo's death.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Do you know that count?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Yes, my lord, and Francisco,

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Bear him these thousand ducats to his lodging;
Tell him the Pope hath sent them. Happily
That will confirm more than all the rest.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: To me sir?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: His holiness hath sent you a thousand crowns,
And will you if you travail, to make him (Commanded.
Your patron for intelligence.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: His creature ever to be
Why now 'tis come about. He railed upon me;
And yet these crowns were told out and laid ready,
Before he knew my voyage. O the art
The modest form of greatness! that do sit
Like brides at wedding dinners, with their looks turned
From the least wanton jests, their puling stomach
Sick of the modesty, when their thoughts are loose.
Even acting of those hot and lustful sports
Are to ensue about midnight: such his cunning!
He sounds my depth thus with a golden plummet,
I am doubly armed now. Now to th'act of blood,
There's but three furies found in spacious hell;
But in a great man's breast three thousand dwell.
sp.stage: A passage over the stage of Brachiano, Flamineo, Marcello, Hortensio, Corombona, Cornelia, Zanche and others.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: In all the weary minutes of my life,
day ne'er broke up till now. This marriage.
Confirms me happy.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: 'Tis a good assurance.
Saw you not yet the Moor that's come to court?

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Yes, and conferred with him i'th Duke's closet,
I have not seen a goodlier personage,
Nor ever talked with man better experienced
In state-affares or rudiments of war.
He hath by report, served the venetian
In Candy these twice seven years, and been chief
In many a bold design.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: What are those two,
That bear him company?

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: Two noblemen of Hungary, that living in the emperor's service as commanders, eight years since, contrary to the expectation of all the court entered into religion, into the strict order of Capuchins: but being not well settled in their undertaking they left their order and returned to court: for which being after troubled in conscience, they vowed their service against the enemies of Christ; went to Malta; were there knighted; and in their return back, at this great solemnity, they are resolved for ever to forsake the world, and settle themselves here in a house of Capuchines in Padua.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: 'Tis strange.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: One thing makes it so. They have vowed for ever to wear next their bare bodies those coats of mail they served in.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Hard penance.
Is the Moor a christian?

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: He is.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Why proffers he his service to our Duke?

sp.speaker: Flu.
sp.l: Because he understands there's like to grow
Some wars between us and the Duke of Florence,
In which he hopes employment.
I never saw one in a stern bold look
Wear more command, nor in a lofty phrase
Express more knowing, or more deep contempt
Of our slight airy courtiers. He talks
As if he had travailed all the prince's courts
Of Christendom; in all things strives t'express,
That all that should dispute with him may know,
Glories, like glowworms, afar off shine bright
but looked to near, have neither heat nor light.
The Duke.
sp.stage: Enter Brachiano, Florence disguised like Mulinassar; Lodovico, Antonelli, Gaspar, Farnese bearing their swords and helmets.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: You're nobly welcome. We have heard at full
Your honourable service 'gainst the Turk.
To you, brave Mulinassar, we assign
A competent pension: and are inly sorrow,
The vows of those two worthy gentlemen,
Make them incapable of our proffered bounty.
Your wish is you may leave your warlike swords
For monuments i in our chapel. I accept it
As a great honour done me, and must crave
Your leave to furnish out our Duchess revels.
Only one thing, as the last vanity
You ere shall view, deny me not to stay
To see a barrier's prepared tonight ;
You shall have private standings: it hath pleased
The great ambassadors of several princes
In their return from Rome to their own countries
To grace our marriage, and to honour me
With such a kind of sport.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I shall persuade them
To stay, my lord.
Set on there to the presence

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Noble my lord, most fortunately welcome,
You have our vows sealed with the sacrament
To second your attempts.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: And all things ready.
He could not have invented his own ruin,
Had he despaired with more propriety.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: You would not take my way.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: 'Tis better ordered.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: 'T'have poisoned his prayer book, or a pair of beads,
The pummel of his saddle, his lookingglass,
Or th'handle of his racket, o that, that!
That while he had been bandying at tennis,
He might have sworn himself to hell, and struck
His soul into the hazard! O my lord!
I would have our plot be ingenious,
and have it hereafter recorded for example
Rather than borrow example.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: There's no way
More speeding than this thought on.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: On then.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: And yet methinks that this revenge is poor,
Because it steals upon him like a thief,
To have ta'en him by the cask in a pitched field,
Led him to Florence!

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: It had been rare. — and there
Have crowned him with a wreath of stinking garlic.
T'have shown the sharpness of his government;
And rankness of his lust.
Flamineo comes.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Why doth this devil haunt you? say.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: I know not.
For by this light I do not conjure for her.
'Tis not so great a cunning as men think
To raise the devil: for here's one up already,
The greatest cunning were to lay him down

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: She is your shame.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: I prithee pardon her.
In faith you see, women are like to burrs;
Where their affection throws them, there they'll stick.

sp.speaker: Zan.
sp.l: That is my countryman, a goodly person;
When he's at leisure I'll discourse with him
In our own language.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: I beseech you do,
How is that brave soldier; o that I had seen
Some of your iron days! I pray relate
Some of your service to us.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: 'Tis a ridiculous thing for a man to be his own chronicle, I did never wash my mouth with mine own praise for fear of getting a stinking breath.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: You're too stoical. The Duke will expect other discourse from you

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p:
I shall never flatter him, I have studied man to much to do that: what difference is between the Duke and I? no more than between two bricks; all made of one clay. Onely't may be one is placed on the top of a turret; the other in the bottom of a well by mere chance; if I were placed as high as the Duke, I should stick as fast; make as fair a show; and bear out
weather equally.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: If this soldier had a patent to beg in churches, than he would tell them storeys,

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I have been a soldier too.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: How have you thrived?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Faith poorly.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: That's the misery of peace. Only outsides are then respected: as ships seem very great upon the river, which show very little upon the seas: so some men i'th court seem colossuses in a chamber, who if they came into the field would appear pitiful. Pigmies.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: Give me a fair room yet hung with arras, and some great Cardinal to lug me by th' ears as his endeared minion.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: And thou mayst do, the devil knows what villainy.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: And safely.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Right; you shall see in the country in harvest time, pigeons, though they destroy never so much corn, the farmer dare not present the fowling piece to them! why? because they belong to the lord of the manor; whilst your poor sparrows that belong to the lord of heaven, they go to the pot for't.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: I will now give you some politic instruction. The Duke says he will give you pension; that's but bare promise: get it under his hand. For I have known men that have come from serving against the Turk; for three or four months they have had pension to buy them new wooden legs and fresh plasters; but after 'twas not to be had. And this miserable courtesy shows, as if a tormenter should give hot cordial drinks to one three quarters dead o'th' rack, only to fetch the miserable soul again to endure more dog-days.
sp.stage: Enter Hortensio, a young lord, Zanche, and two more.
sp.l: How now, gallants; what are they ready for the barriers?

sp.speaker: Y. lord.
sp.l: Yes: the lords are putting on their armour.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: What's he?

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: A new upstart: one that swears like a falconer, and will lie in the Duke's ear day by day like a maker of almanacs; and yet I knew him since he came to th' court smell worse of sweat than an under-tennis-court keeper.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Look you, yonder's your sweet mistress.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: Thou art my sworn brother, I'll tell thee, I do love that Moor, that witch very constrainedly: she knows some of my villainy; I do love her, just as a man holds a wolf by the ears. But for fear of turning upon me, and pulling out my throat, I would let her go to the devil.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: I hear she claims marriage of thee.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: I'faith, I made to her some such dark promise, and in seeking to fly from't I run on, like a frighted dog with a bottle at 'stail, that fain would bite it off and yet dares not look behind him. Now my precious Gipsy!

sp.speaker: Zan.
sp.l: I your love to me rather cools then heats.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: Marry, I am the sounder, lover, we have many wenches about the town heat too fast.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: What do you think of these perfumed gallants then?

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.l: Their satin cannot save them. I am confident
They have a certain spice of the disease,
For they that sleep with dogs; shall rise with fleas.

sp.speaker: Zan.
sp.l: Believe it! A little painting and gay clothes,
Make you loathe me.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: How? love a lady for painting or gay apparel? I'll unkennel one example more for thee. Aesop had a foolish dog that let go the flesh to catch the shadow. I would have courtiers be better divers.

sp.speaker: Zan.
sp.l: You remember your oaths.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: Lover's oaths are like mariners prayers, uttered in extremity; but when the tempest is o'er, and that the vessel leaves tumbling, they fall from protesting to drinking. And yet amongst gentlemen protesting and drinking go together, and agree as well as shoemakers and Westphalia bacon. They are both drawers on: for drink draws on protestation; and protestation draws on more drink. Is not this discourse better now than the mortality of your sunburnt gentleman.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Is this your perch, you haggard? fly to'th stews.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: You should be clapped by th'heels now: strike i'th court.

sp.speaker: Zan.
sp.l: She's good for nothing but to make her maids,
Catch cold a nights; they dare not use a bedstaff,
For fear of her light fingers.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: You're a strumpet.
An impudent one.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Why do you kick her? say,
do you think that she's like a walnut-tree?
Must she be cudgeled ere she bear good fruit?
She brags that you shall marry her.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: What then?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I had rather she were pitched upon a stake
In some new-seeded garden, to affright
Her fellow crows thence.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Your a boy, a fool,
Be guardian to your hound, I am of age.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: If I take her near you I'll cut her throat.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: With a fan of feathers?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: And for you; I'll whip
This folly from you.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.l: Are you choleric?
I'll purg't with rhubarb.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: O your brother.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Hang him.
He wrongs me most that ought t'offend me least,
I do suspect my mother foul soul play,
When she conceived thee.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Now by all my hopes.
Like the two slaughtered sons of Oedipus,
The very flames of our affection,
Shall turn 10 ways. Those words I'll make thee answer
With thy heart blood.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Do like the geese in the progress,
You know where you shall find me,

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Very good,
And thou beest a noble, friend, bear him my sword,
And bid him fit the length on't.

sp.speaker: Y. lord.
sp.l: Sir I shall.

sp.speaker: Zan.
sp.l: He comes. Hence petty thought of my disgrace,
I ne'er loved my complexion till now,
sp.stage: Enter Francisco the Duke of Florence.
sp.l: 'Cause I may boldly say without a blush,
I love you.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Your love is untimely sown,
There's a spring at Michaelmas, but 'tis but a faint one, I am sunk
In years, and I have vowed never to marry.

sp.speaker: Zan.
sp.l: Alas! poor maids get more lovers than husbands,
sp.p: Yet you may mistake my wealth. For, as when ambassadors are sent to congratulate princes, there's commonly sent along with them a rich present; so that though the prince like not the ambassadors person nor words, yet he likes well of the presentment. So I may come to you in the same manner, and be better loved for my dowry then my virtue.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: I'll think on the motion.

sp.speaker: Zan.
sp.p: Do, I'll now detain you no longer. At your better leisure I'll tell you things shall startle your blood.
sp.l: Nor blame me that this passion I reveal;
lovers die inward that their flames conceal.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Of all intelligence this may prove the best,
Sure I shall draw strange fowl, from this foul nest.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: I hear a whispering all about the court,
You are to fight, who is your opposite?
What is the quarrel?

sp.speaker: Mra.
sp.l: 'Tis an idle rumour.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Will you dissemble? sure you do not well
To fright me thus, you never look thus pale,
But when you are most angry. I do charge you
Upon my blessing; nay I'll call the Duke,
And he shall school you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Publish not a fear
Which would convert to laughter; 'tis not so,
Was not this crucifix my fathers?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I have heard you say, giving my brother suck,
He took the crucifix between his hands,
And broke a limb off.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Yes: but 'tis mended.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: I have brought your weapon back.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Ha, oh my horror!

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: You have brought it home indeed.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Help, o he's murdered.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Do you turn your gall up? I'll to sanctuary,
And send a surgeon to you.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: How? o'th ground?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: O mother now remember what I told,
Of breaking off the crucifix: farewell
There are some sins which heaven doth duly punish,
In a whole family. This it is to rise
By all dishonest means. Let all men know
That tree shall long time keep a steady foot
Whose branches spread no wilder than the root.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: O my perpetual sorrow!

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Virtuous Marcello.
He's dead: pray leave him lady; come, you shall.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Alas he is not dead: he's in a trance.
sp.p: Why here's nobody shall get any thing by his death. Let me call him again for god's sake.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I would you were deceived.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p:
O you abuse me, you abuse me, you abuse me. How many have gone away thus for lack of tendance; rear up's head,
rear up's head; his bleeding inward will kill him.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: You see he is departed.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Let me come to him; give me him as he is, if he be turned to earth; let me but give him one hearty kiss, and you shall put us both into one coffin: fetch a looking glass, see if his breath will not stain it; or pull out some feathers from my pillow, and lay them to his lips, will you lose him for a little pains taking?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Your kindest office is to pray for him.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Alas! I would not pray for him yet. He may live to lay me ith' ground, and pray for me, if you'll let me come to him.
sp.stage: Enter Brachiano all armed, save the beaver, with Flamineo.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Was this your handiwork?

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: It was my misfortune.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: He lies, he lies, he did not kill him: these have killed him, that would not let him be better looked to.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Have comfort my grieved mother.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: O you screech-owl.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Forbear, good madam.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Let me go, let me go.
sp.stage: She runes to Flamineo with her knife drawn and coming to him lets it fall.
sp.l: The god of heaven forgive thee. Dost not wonder
I pray for thee? I'll tell thee what's the reason,
I have scarce breath to number twenty minutes;
I'd not spend that in cursing. Fare thee well
Half of thyself lies there: and mayst thou live
To fill an hourglass with his mouldered ashes,
To tell how thou shouldst spend the time to come
In blessed repentance.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Mother, pray tell me
How came he by his death? what was the quarrel?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Indeed my younger boy presumed too much
Upon his manhood; gave him bitter words;
Drew his sword first; and so I know not how,
For I was out of my wits, he fell with's head
Just in my bosom.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: This is not true madam.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: I pray thee peace.
One arrow's grazed already; it were vain
T'lose this: for that will ne'er be found again.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Go, bear the body to Corneliá; lodging:
And we command that none acquaint our Duchess:
with this sad accident: for you Flamineo,
Hark you, I will not grant your pardon.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: No?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Only a lease of your life. And that shall last
sp.p: But for one day. Thou shalt be forced each evening to renew it, or be hanged.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: At your pleasure.
sp.stage: Lodovico sprinkles Brachiano's beaver with a poison.
sp.l: Your will is law now, I'll not meddle with it.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: You once did brave me in your sister's lodging;
I'll now keep you in awe for't. Where's our beaver?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: He calls for his destruction. Noble youth,
I pity thy sad fate. Now to the barriers.
This shall his passage to the black lake further,
The last good deed he did, he pardoned murder.
sp.stage: Charges and shouts, they fight at barriers; first single pairs, then three to three.
Enter Brachiano and Flamineo with others.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: An armourer? uds death an armourer?

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Armorer; where's the armourer?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Tear off my beaver.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Are you hurt, my lord?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: O my brain's on fire,
The helmet is poisoned.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: My lord upon my soul.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Away with him to torture.
There are some great ones that have hand in this,
And near about me.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: O my loved lord, poisoned?

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Remove the bar: here's unfortunate revels,
Call the physicians; a plague upon you;
We have to much of your cunning here already.
I fear the ambassadors are likewise poisoned.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: O I am gone already: the infection
Flies to the brain and heart. O thou strong heart!
There's such a covenant between the world and it,
They're loath to break.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: O my most loved father!

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Remove the boy away,
Where's this good woman? had I infinite worlds
They were too little for thee. Must I leave thee?
What say you screech-owls, is the venom mortal?

sp.speaker: Phys.
sp.l: Most deadly.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Most corrupted politic hangman!
You kill without book; but your art to save
Fails you as oft, as great men's needy friends.
I that have given life to offending slaves
And wretched murderers, have I not power
To lengthen mine own a twelvemonth?
Do not kiss me, for I shall poison thee.
This unction is sent from the great Duke of Florence.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Sir be of comforts

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: O thou soft natural death, that art joint-twin,
To sweetest slumber: no rough-bearded comet,
Stares on thy mild departure: the dull owl
Beats not against thy casement: the hoarse wolf
Scents not thy carrion. Pity winds thy corse,
Whilst horror weights on princes.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: I am lost for ever.

sp.speaker: Brac.
sp.l: How miserable a thing it is to die,
Amongst women howling! What are those.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Franciscant.
They have brought the extreme unction.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: On pain of death, let no man name death to me,
It is a word infinitely terrible,
Withdraw into our cabinet

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: To see what solitariness is about dying princes. As heretofore they have unpeopled towns; divorced friends, and made great houses unhospitable: so now, o justice! where are their flatterers now? Flatterers are but the shadows of prince's bodies the least thick cloud makes them invisible.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: There's great moan made for him.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: I'faith, for some few hour's salt water will run most plentifully in every office o'th court. But believe it; most of them do but weep over their stepmother's graves.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: How mean you?

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: Why? They dissemble, as some men do that live within compass o'th verge.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Come you have thrived well under him.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: I'faith, like a wolf in a woman's breast; I have been fed with poultry; but for money, understand me, I had as good a will to cozen him, as e'er an officer of them all. But I had not cunning enough to do it.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: What didst thou think of him; i'faith speak freely.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: He was a kind of statesman, that would sooner have reckoned how many cannon bullets he had discharged against a town, to count his expense that way, than how many of his valiant and deserving subjects he lost before it.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: O, speak well of the Duke.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: I have done.
Will't hear some of my court wisdom?
To reprehend princes is dangerous: and to over-commend some
Of them is palpable lying.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: How is it with the Duke?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Most deadly ill.
He's fallen into a strange distraction.
He talks of battles and monopolies,
Levying of taxes, and from that descends
To the most brainsick language. His mind fastens
On twenty several objects, which confound
Deep sense with folly. Such a fearful end
May teach some men that bear too lofty crest,
Though they live happiest, yet they die not best.
He hath conferred the whole state of the dukedom
Upon your sister, till the prince arrive
At mature age.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: There's some good luck in that yet.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: See here he comes.
sp.stage: Enter Brachiano, presented in a bed Uittoria and others.
sp.l: There's death in's face already.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: O my good lord!

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Away, you have abused me.
You have conveyed coin forth our territories;
Bought and sold offices; oppressed the poor,
sp.stage: These speeches are several kinds of distractions and in the action should appear so.
sp.l: And I ne'er dreamt on't. Make up your accounts;
I'll now be mine own steward.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Sir, have patience.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Indeed I am too blame.
For did you ever hear the dusky raven
Chide blackness? or wast ever known, the devil
Railed against cloven creatures.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: O my lord!

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Let me have some quails to supper.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Sir, you shall.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: No: some fried dogfish. Your quails feed on poison,
That old dog-fox, that politician Florence,
I'll forswear hunting and turn dog-killer;
Rare! I'll be friends with him. for mark you, sir, one dog
still sets another a barking: peace, peace,
Yonder's a fine slave come in now.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Where?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Why there.
In a blue bonnet, and a pair of breeches
With a great codpiece. Ha, ha, ha,
Look you his codpiece is stuck full of pins
With pearls o'th head of them. Do not you know him?

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: No, my lord.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Why 'tis the devil.
I know him by a great rose he wears on's shoe
To hide his cloven foot. I'll dispute with him.
He's a rare linguist.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: My lord here's nothing.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Nothing? rare! nothing! when I want money,
Our treasury is empty; there is nothing,
I'll not be used thus.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: O! 'Lie still, my lord

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: See, see, Flamineo that killed his brother
Is dancing on the ropes there: and he carries
A moneybag in each hand, to keep him even,
For fear of breaking's neck. And there's a lawyer
In a gown whipped with velvet, stares and gapes
When the money will fall. How the rogue cuts capers!
It should have been in a halter.
'Tis there; what's she?

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Vittoria, my lord.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha. Her hair is sprinkled with arras powder, that makes her look as if she had sinned in the pastry. What's he?

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: A divine my lord.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: He will be drunk: avoid him: th' argument is fearful when churchmen stagger in't.
sp.stage: Brachiano seems hear near his end. Lodovico and Gasparo in the habit of Capuchins present him in his bed with a crucifix and hallowed candle.
sp.p: Look you; six grey rats that have lost their tails, crawl up the pillow, send for a rat-catcher.
I'll do a miracle: I'll free the court
From all foul vermin. Where's Flamineo?

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: I do not like that he names me so often,
Especially on's deathbed: 'tis a sign
I shall not live long: see he's near his end.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Pray give us leave; attend dominae brachianus,

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: See, see, how firmly he doth fix his eye
Upon the crucifix.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: O hold it constant.
It settles his wild spirits; and so his eyes
Melt into tears.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Dominae brachianus, solebas in bello tutus esse tuo clypeo, nùnc hunc clypeum hostituo opponas infernali.

sp.speaker: Gas.
sp.p: Olim hasta valuisti in bello; nùnc hanc sacram hastam vibrabis contra hostem animarum.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Attend dominae brachianus si nunc quòque probas ea quae acta sunt inter nos, flecte caput in dextrum.

sp.speaker: Gas.
sp.p: Esto securus dominae brachianus: cogita quantum habeas meritorum denique memineris meam animam pro tua oppignoratem si quid esset periculi.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Si nùnc quoque probas ea quae acta sunt inter nos, flecte caput in lewm.
sp.l: He is departing: pray stand all apart,
And let us only whisper in his ears
Some private meditations, which our order
sp.stage: Hear therest being departed Lodovico and Gasparo discover themselves.
sp.l: Permits you not to hear.

sp.speaker: Gas.
sp.l: Brachiano.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Devil Brachiano.
Thou art damned.

sp.speaker: Gas.
sp.l: Perpetually.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: A slave condemned, and given up to the gallows
Is thy great lord and master.

sp.speaker: Gas.
sp.l: True: for thou
Art given up to the devil.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: O you slave!
You that were held the famous politician;
Whose art was poison.

sp.speaker: Gas.
sp.l: And whose conscience murder.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: That would have broke your wife's neck down the stairs ere she was poisoned.

sp.speaker: Gas.
sp.l: That had your villainous

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: And fine embroidered bottles, (Salads
And perfumes
Equally mortal with a winter plague

sp.speaker: Gas.
sp.l: Now there's mercury.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: And copperas

sp.speaker: Gas.
sp.l: And quicksilver.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: With other devilish pothecary stuff
A melting in your politic brains: dost hear.

sp.speaker: Gas.
sp.l: This is count Lodovico.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: This Gasparo.
And thou shalt die like a poor rogue.

sp.speaker: Gas.
sp.l: And stink
Like a dead fly-blown dog.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: And be forgotten before thy funeral sermon.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Vittoria? Vittoria!

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: O the cursed devil,
Come to himself a gain. We are undone.
(Again

sp.speaker: Gas.
sp.l: Strangle him in private. What? will you call him
To live in treble torments? for charity,
For Christian charity, avoid the chamber.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: You would prate, sir. This is a true-love knot
Sent from the Duke of Florence.

sp.speaker: Gas.
sp.l: What is it done?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: The snuff is out. No woman-keeper i'th world,
Though she had practised seven year at the pest-house,
Could have done't quaintlier. My lords he's dead.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Rest to his soul.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: O me! this place is hell.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: How heavily she takes it.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: O yes, yes;
Had women navigable rivers in their eyes
They would dispend them all; surely I wonder
Why we should wish more rivers to the city,
When they sell water so good cheap. I'll tell thee,
These are but moonish shades of griefs or fears,
There's nothing sooner dry than womens-tears.
Why here's an end of all my harvest, he has given me nothing
Court promises! Let wise-men count them cursed
For while you live he that scores best pays worst.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Sure, this was Florence doing.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Very likely.
Those are found weighty strokes which come from th'hand,
But those are killing strokes which come from th'head.
O the rare tricks of a machiavellian!
He doth not come like a gross plodding slave
And buffet you to death: no, my quaint knave,
He tickles you to death; makes you die laughing;
As if you had swallowed down a pound of saffron
You see the seat, 'tis practised in a trice
To teach court-honesty, it jumps on ice.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Now have the people liberty to talk
And descant on his vices.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Misery of princes,
That must of force be censured by their slaves!
Not only blamed for doing things are ill,
But for not doing all that all men will.
One were better be a thresher.
Uds'death, I would fain speak with this Duke yet.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Now he's dead?

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.l: I cannot conjure; but if prayers or oaths
Will get to th'speech of him: though forty devil's
Weight on him in his livery of flames,
I'll speak to him, and shake him by the hand,
Though I be blasted.

sp.speaker: Fra
sp.l: Excellent Lodovico!
What? did you terrify him at the last gasp?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Yes; and so idly, that the Duke had like
T'have terrified us.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: You shall hear that hereafter,
See! yon's the infernal, that would make up sport.
Now to the revelation of that secret,
She promised when she fell in love with you.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: You're passionately met in this sad world.

sp.speaker: Moo.
sp.l: I would have you look up, sir; these court tears
Claim not your tribute to them. Let those weep
That guiltily partake in the sad cause.
I knew last night by a sad dream I had
Some mischief would ensue; yet to say truth
My dream most concerned you.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Shall's fall a dreaming?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Yes, and for fashion's sake I'll dream with her.

sp.speaker: Moo.
sp.l: Methought sir, you came stealing to my bed.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Wilt thou believe me sweeting; by this light
I was a dreamt on thee too: for methought
I saw thee naked

sp.speaker: Moo.
sp.l: Fie sir! as I told you,
Methought you lay down by me.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: So dreamt I;
And lest thou shouldst take cold, I covered thee
With this Irish mantle.

sp.speaker: Moo.
sp.l: Verily I did dream,
You were some what bold with me; but to come to't.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: How? how? I hope you will not go to there.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Nay: you must hear my dream out.

sp.speaker: Moors.
sp.l: Well, sir, forth.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: When I threw the mantle o'er thee, thou didst laugh
Exceedingly methought .

sp.speaker: Moors.
sp.l: Laugh?

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: And cried'st out,
The hair did tickle thee.

sp.speaker: Moo.
sp.l: There was a dream indeed.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Mark her I prithee, she simpers like the suds
A collier hath been washed in.

sp.speaker: Moo.
sp.l: Come, sir; good fortune tends you; I did tell you
I would reveal a secret, Isabella
The Duke of Florence sister was empoisoned,
By a 'Fumed picture: and Camillo's neck
Was broke by damned Flamineo; the mischance
Laid on a vaulting horse.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Most strange!

sp.speaker: Moo.
sp.l: Most true.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: The bed of snakes is broke.

sp.speaker: Moo.
sp.l: I sadly do confess I had a hand
In the black deed.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Thou kep'st their counsel,

sp.speaker: Moo.
sp.l: Right,
For which, urged with contrition, I intend
This night to rob Vittoria.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Excellent penitence!
Usurer's dream on't while they sleep out sermons.

sp.speaker: Moo.
sp.l: To further our escape, I have entreated
Leave to retire me, till the funeral,
Unto a friend i'th country. That excuse
Will further our escape, in coin and jewels
I shall, at least, make good unto your use
An hundred thousand crowns.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: O noble wench!

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Those crowns we'll share.

sp.speaker: Moo.
sp.l: It is a dowry,
Methinks , should make that sunburnt proverb false,
And wash the Aethiop white.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: It shall, away

sp.speaker: Moo.
sp.l: Be ready for our flight.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: An hour 'fore day.
O strange discovery! why till now we knew not
The circumstance of either of their deaths.

sp.speaker: Moo.
sp.l: You'll weight about midnight
In the chapel.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: There.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Why now our action's justified,

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Tush for justice.
What harms it justice? we now, like the partridge
purge the disease with laurel: for the fame
Shall crown the enterprise and quit the shame.
sp.stage: Enter Flam. and Gasp. at one door, another way Giovanni attended.

sp.speaker: Gas.
sp.l: The young Duke: did you e'er see a sweeter prince?

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: I have known a poor woman's bastard better favoured, this is behind him: now, to his face all comparisons were hateful: wise was the courtly peacock, that being a great minion, and being compared for beauty, by some dotterels that stood by, to the kingly eagle, said the eagle was a far fairer bird than herself, not in respect of her feathers, but in respect of her long talons. His will grow out in time,
My gracious lord.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: I pray leave me sir.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: Your grace must be merry: 'tis I have cause to mourn, for wot you what said the little boy that road behind his father on horseback?

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Why, what said he?

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: When you are dead father (Said he) I hope then I shall ride in the saddle, oh 'tis a brave thing for a man to sit by himself: he may stretch himself in the stirrups, look about, and see the whole compass of the hemisphere, you're now, my lord, ith' saddle.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Study your prayers, sir, and be penitent,
'Twere fit you'd think on what hath former been,
I have heard grief named the eldest child of sin.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Study my prayers? he threatens me divinely,
I am falling to pieces already, I care not, though, like Anacharsis
sp.p: I were pounded to death in a mortar. And yet that death were fitter for usurer's gold and themselves to be beaten together, to make a most cordial cullis for the devil.
sp.l: He hath his uncles villainous look already,
In dicimo sexto. Now sir, what are you?

sp.speaker: Covr
sp.l: It is the pleasure sir, of the young Duke
That you forbear the presence, and all room,
That owe him reverence.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: So, the wolf and the raven are very pretty fools when they are young. Is it your office, sir, to keep me out?

sp.speaker: Covr.
sp.l: So the Duke wills.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p:
Verily, master courtier, extremity is not to be used
in all offices: say that a gentlewoman were taken out of her bed about midnight, and committed to castle Angelo, to the tower yonder, with nothing about her, but her smock: would it not show a cruel part in the gentleman porter to lay claim to her upper garment, pull it o'er her head and ears; and put her in naked?

sp.speaker: Covr.
sp.l: Very good: you are merry

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: Doth he make a court ejectment of me? A flaming firebrand casts more smoke without a chimney, then within't. I'll smoor some of them.
sp.l: How now? Thou heart sad.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I met even now with the most piteous sight.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Thou metst another hair a pitiful
Degraded courtier.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Your reverend mother
Is grown a very old woman in two hours.
I found them winding of Marcello's corse;
And there is such a solemn melody
Between doleful songs, tears, and sad elegies:
Such, as old grandames, watching by the dead,
Were wont t'outwear the nights with; that believe me
I had no eyes to guide me forth the room,
They were so o'ercharged with water.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: I will see them.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: 'Twere much uncharity in you: for your sight
Will add unto their tears.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: I will see them.
They are behind the travers. I'll discover
Their superstitious howling.
sp.stage: Cornelia, the Moor and 3. other ladies discovered, winding Marcello's corpse. A song.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: This rosemary is withered, pray get fresh;
I would have these herbs grow up in his grave
When I am dead and rotten. Reach the bays,
I'll tie a garland here about his head:
'Twill keep my boy from lightning. This sheet
I have kept this twenty year, and every day
Hallowed it with my prayers, I did not think
He should have wore it.

sp.speaker: Moo.
sp.l: Look you; who are yonder.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: O reach me the flowers.

sp.speaker: Moo.
sp.l: Her ladyship's foolish.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.l: Alas! her grief
hath turned her child again.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: You're very welcome.
There's rosemary for you, and rue for you,
Hearts-ease for you. I pray make much of it.
I have left more for myself.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Lady, who's this?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: You are, I take it, the grave-maker.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: So.

sp.speaker: Moo.
sp.l: 'Tis Flamineo.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Will you make me such a fool? here's a white hand:
Can blood so soon be washed out? Let me see,
When screech-owls croak upon the chimney tops,
And the strange Cricketith oven sings and hops,
When yellow spots do on your hands appear,
Be certain then you of a course shall hear.
Out upon't, how 'tis speckled! has handled a toad sure.
Cowslip-water is good for the memory: pray buy me 3. ounces of't.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: I would I were from hence.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Do you here,
I'll give you a saying which my grandmother (Sir?
Was wont, when she heard the bell tolle, to sing o'er unto her lute

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Do and you will, do.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Call for the robin-redbreast and the wren,
Since o'er shady groves they hover,
sp.stage: Cornelia doth this in several forms of distraction.
sp.l: And with leaves and flowers do cover
The friendless bodies of unburied men.
Call unto his funeral dole
The ant, the fieldmouse, and the mole
To rear him hillocks, that shall keep him warm,
And (When gay tombs are robbed) sustain no harm,
But keep the wolf far thence: that's foe to men,
For with his nails he'll dig them up again.
They would not bury him 'cause he died in a quarrel
But I have an answer for them.
Let holy church receive him duly
Since he paid the church tithes truly.
His wealth is summed, and this is all his store:
This poor men get; and great men get no more.
Now the wares are gone, we may shut up shop.
Bless you all good people,

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: I have a strange thing in me, to th' which
I cannot give a name, without it be
Compassion, I pray leave me.
This night I'll know the utmost most of my fate ▪
I'll be resolved what my rich sister means
T'assign me for my service: I have lived
Riotously ill, like some that live in court.
And sometimes, when my face was full of smiles ▪
Have felt the maze of conscience in my breast.
Oft gay and honoured robes those tortures try,
"We think caged birds sing, when indeed they cry.
Ha! I can stand thee. Nearer, nearer yet.
sp.stage: In his leather cassock and breeches boots, acoo● a pot of lily flowers with a scullint.
sp.l: What a mockery hath death made of thee? thou lookest sad.
In what place art thou? in you starry gallery,
Or in the cursed dungeon? No? not speak?
Pray, sir, resolve me, what religions best
For a man to die in? or is it in your knowledge
To answer me how long I have to live?
That's the most necessary question.
Not answer? Are you still like some great men
That only walk like shadows up and down,
And to no purpose: say: —
sp.stage: The ghost throws earth upon him and shows him the scull.
sp.l: What's that? O fatal! he throws earth upon me ▪
A dead man's scull beneath the roots of flowers.
I pray speak sir, our Italian churchmen
Make us believe, dead men hold conference
With their familiars, and many times
Will come to bed to them, and eat with them.
He's gone; and see, the scull and earth are vanished.
This is beyond melancholy. I do dare my fate
To do its worst. Now to my sister's lodging,
And sum up all these horrors; the disgrace
The prince threw on me; next the piteous sight
Of my dead brother; and my mother's dotage;
And last this terrible vision. All these
Shall with Vittoria's bounty turn to good,
Or I will drown this weapon in her blood.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: My lord upon my soul you shall no further:
You have most ridiculously engaged yourself
Too far already. For my part, I have paid
All my debts, so if I should chance to fall
My creditors fall not with me; and I vow
To quite all in this bold assembly
To the meanest follower. My lord leave the city,
Or I'll forswear the murder.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Farewell Lodovico.
If thou dost perish in this glorious act,
I'll rear unto thy memory that fame
Shall in the ashes keep alive thy name.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: There's some black deed on foot. I'll presently
Down to the citadel, and raise some force.
These strong court factions that do brook no checks,
In the career of't break the rider's necks.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: What are you at your prayers? Give o'er.
sp.stage: Enter Vittoria with a book in her hand. Zanke, Flamineo, following them.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: How Ruffin?

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: I come to you about worldly business:
Sit down, sit down: nay stay blouze, you may hear it,
The doors are fast enough.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: Ha, are you drunk?

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Yes, yes, with wormwood water, you shall taste
Some of it presently.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: What intends the fury?

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: You are my lords executrix, and I claim
Reward, for my long service.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: For your service

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Come therefore here is pen and ink, set down
What you will give me.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: There,

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Ha! have you done already,
'Tis a most short conveyance.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: I will read it.
I give that portion to thee, and no other
Which Cain groaned under having slain his brother.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: A most courtly patent to beg by.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: You are a villain.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Is't come to this? the say affrights cure agues:
Thou hast a devil in thee; I will try
If I can scar him from thee: nay sit still:
My lord hath left me yet two case of jewels
Shall make me scorn your bounty; you shall see them.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: Sure he's distracted.

sp.speaker: Zan.
sp.l: O he's desperate
sp.stage: He enter with two of pistol●
sp.l: For your own safety give him gentle language.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Look, these are better far at a dead list,
Than all your jewel house.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: And yet methinks ,
These stones have no fair lustre, they are ill set.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: I'll turn the right side towards you: you shall see how the will sparkle.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: Turn this horror from me:
What do you want? what would you have me do?
Is not all mine, yours? have I any children?

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Pray there good woman do not trouble me
With this vain worldly business; say your prayers,
I made a vow to my deceased lord,
Neither yourself, nor I should outlive him,
The numbring of four hours.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: Did he enjoin it.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: He did, and 'twas a deadly jealousy,
Lest any should enjoy thee after him;
That urged him vow me to it: for my death
I did propound it voluntarily, knowing
If he could not be safe in his own court
Being a great Duke, what hope then for us?

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: This is your melancholy and despair.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Away,
Fool, thou art to think that politicians
Do use to kill the effects of injuries
And let the cause live: shall we groan in irons,
Or be a shameful and a weighty burden
To a public scaffold: this is my resolve
I would not live at any man's entreaty
Nor die at any's bidding.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: Will you hear me?

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: My life hath done service to other men,
My death shall serve mine own turn; make you ready

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: Do you mean to die indeed.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: With as much pleasure
As e'er my father got me.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: Are the doors locked?

sp.speaker: Zan.
sp.l: Yes madam.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: Are you grown an atheist? will you turn your body,
Which is the goodly palace of the soul
To the soul's slaughter house? O the cursed devil
which doth present us with all other sins
Thrice candied o'er; despair with gall and stibium,
Yet we carouse it off; cry out for help,
Makes us forsake that which was made for man,
The world, to sink to that was made for devils,
Eternal darkness.

sp.speaker: Zan.
sp.l: Help, help.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: I'll stop your
With winter plums,

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: I prithee yet remember, (Throat
Millions are now in graves, which at last day
Like mandrakes shall rise shrieking.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Leave your prating,
For these are but grammatical laments,
Feminine arguments, and they move me
As some in pulpits move their auditory
More with their exclamation then sense
Of reason, or sound doctrine.

sp.speaker: Zan.
sp.l: Gentle madam
Seem to consent, only persuade him teach
The way to death; let him die first.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: 'Tis good, I apprehend it,
To kill one's self is meat that we must take
Like pills, not chew't, but quickly swallow it,
The smart a'th wound, or weakness of the hand
May else bring treble torments.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: I have held it
A wretched and most miserable life,
Which is not able to die.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: O but frailty!
Yet I am now resolved, farewell affliction;
Behold Brachiano, I that while you lived
Did make a flaming altar of my heart
To sacrifice unto you; now am ready
To sacrifice heart and all. Farewell Zanche.

sp.speaker: Zan.
sp.l: How madam! Do you think that I'll outlive you?
Especially when my best self Flamineo
Goes the same voyage.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Oh most loved Moor!

sp.speaker: Zan.
sp.l: Only by all my love let me entreat you;
Since it is most necessary none of us
Do violence on ourselves; let you or I
Be her sad taster, teach her how to die.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Thou dost instruct me nobly, take these pistols,
Because my hand is stained with blood already:
two of these you shall level at my breast,
Th'other 'gainst your own, and so we'll die,
Most equally contented: but first swear
Not to outlive me.

sp.speaker: Vit. and Moo.
sp.l: Most religiously.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Then here's an end of me: farewell daylight
And o contemptible physic! that dost take
So long a study, only to preserve
So short a life, I take my leave of thee.
These are two cupping-glasses, that shall draw
All my infected blood out,
Are you ready?

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: Ready.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: Whither shall I go now? O Lucian thy ridiculous purgatory to find Alexander the great cobbling shoes, Pompey tagging points, and Julius Caesar; making hair buttons, Hannibal selling blacking, and Augustus crying garlic, Charlemagne selling lists by the dozen, and King Pippin crying apples in a cart drawn with one horse.
sp.l: Whether I resolve to fire, earth, water, air,
Or all the elements by scruples; I know not
Nor greatly care, — shoot, shoot,
Of all deaths the violent death is best,
For from ourselves it steals ourselves so fast
sp.stage: They shoot and run to him and tr●● upon him.
sp.l: The pain once apprehended is quite past.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: What are you dropped.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: I am mixed with earth already: as you are noble perform your vows, and bravely follow me.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: Whither to hell,

sp.speaker: Zan.
sp.l: To most assured damnation.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: O thou most cursed devil.

sp.speaker: Zan.
sp.l: Thou art caught

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: In thine own engine, I tread the fire out
That would have been my ruin.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: Will you be perjured? what a religious oath was Styx that the gods never durst swear by and violate? O that we had such an oath to minister, and to be so well kept in our courts of justice.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: Think whither thou art going.

sp.speaker: Zan.
sp.l: And remember
What villainies thou hast acted.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: This thy death,
Shall make me like a blazing ominous star,
Look up and tremble.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: O I am caught with a spring!

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: You see the fox comes many times short ho me,
'Tis here proved true.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Killed with a couple of branches.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: No fitter offering for the infernal furies
Then one in whom they reigned while he was living.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: O the ways dark and horrid! I cannot see,
Shall I have no company?

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: O yes thy sins,
Do run before thee to fetch fire from hell,
To light thee thither.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: O I smell soot, most sinking soot, the chimneys a fire,
My livers purboiled like Scotch holly-bread;
There's a plumber, laying pipes in my guts, it scalds;
Wilt thou outlive me?

sp.speaker: Zan.
sp.l: Yes, and drive a stake
Through thy body; for we'll give it out,
Thou didst this violence upon thyself.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Oh cunning devils! now I have tried your love,
And doubled all your reaches. I am not wounded:
The pistols held no bullets: 'twas a plot
To prove your kindness to me; and I live
To punish your ingratitude, I knew
One time or other you would find a way
To give me a strong potion, ò men
That lie upon your deathbeds, and are haunted
With howling wives, near trust them, they'll remarry
Ere the worm pierce your winding sheet: ere the spider
Make a thin curtain for your epitaphs.
sp.p: How cunning you were to discharge? Do you practise at the artillery yard? Trust a woman; never, never; Brachiano be my precedent: we lay our souls to pawn to the devil for a little pleasure, and a woman makes the bill of sale. That ever man should marry! For one Hypermnestra that saved her lord and husband, forty nine of her sisters cut their husband's throats all in one night. There was a shoal of virtuous horseleeches.
Here are two other instruments.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: Help, help.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: What noise is that? hah? false keys i'th court.

sp.speaker: Lod.
